You said:
consider the following linear model: To model the latent variable $\mathcal{Y}$, we use a two-way (two factors) or a three-way (three factors) mixed-effects model. For simplicity, we explain here the model for two factors. Its extension to three factors is straightforward. The model has the following form: $$ y_{ijk} = \mu + s_k + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12} x_{1i} x_{2j} + \epsilon_{ijk} $${#eq-linear-model} - $\mu$ is the grand mean - $s_k$ is the random intercept effect of the *k*-th subject, where $k = 1..n$ - $x_{1i}$ is a numerical encoding of the *i*-th level of factor $X_1$, where $i = 1..m_1$ - $x_{2j}$ is a numerical encoding of the *j*-th level of factor $X_2$, where $j = 1..m_2$ - $a_1$, $a_2$, and $a_{12}$ express the magnitude of main and interaction effects - $\epsilon_{ijk}$ is the experimental error effect
ChatGPT said:

Nice model thanks for the clear statement. Ill give a compact, practical reference for that two-factor mixed model: matrix form, distributional assumptions, variance decomposition, estimation (REML / mixed-model equations), interpretation (coding, centering), hypothesis testing, diagnostics, and the straightforward extension to three factors. Ill also include ready-to-run R code (lme4) you can drop into your analysis.

Model and distributional assumptions

You wrote

yijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j+ijk,y_{ijk} = \mu + s_k + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12} x_{1i} x_{2j} + \epsilon_{ijk},yijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j+ijk,

with k=1,,nk=1,\dots,nk=1,,n, i=1,,m1i=1,\dots,m_1i=1,,m1, j=1,,m2j=1,\dots,m_2j=1,,m2.

Assume

  • skiidN(0,s2)s_k \overset{\text{iid}}{\sim} \mathcal N(0,\sigma_s^2)skiidN(0,s2) (random subject intercepts),

  • ijkiidN(0,2)\epsilon_{ijk}\overset{\text{iid}}{\sim}\mathcal N(0,\sigma_\epsilon^2)ijkiidN(0,2) (residual noise),

  • sks_ksk independent of ijk\epsilon_{ijk}ijk.

(If you prefer subject slopes or other random terms, add them to sks_ksk or expand the random effect vector.)

Vector / matrix form (Mixed model)

Let yyy be the stacked vector of observations. Put fixed-effect parameters in \beta and random subject intercepts in uuu. A usual representation:

y=X+Zu+,y = X\beta + Z u + \epsilon,y=X+Zu+,

where

  • XXX is the design matrix for fixed effects (columns: intercept, x1x_1x1, x2x_2x2, x1x2x_1x_2x1x2),

  • =(,a1,a2,a12)\beta = (\mu, a_1, a_2, a_{12})^\top=(,a1,a2,a12),

  • ZZZ is the design matrix for random subject intercepts (one column per subject; row has 1 for subject of that observation, 0 otherwise),

  • u=(s1,,sn)N(0,G)u = (s_1,\dots,s_n)^\top\sim\mathcal N(0,G)u=(s1,,sn)N(0,G) with G=s2InG = \sigma_s^2 I_nG=s2In,

  • N(0,R)\epsilon\sim\mathcal N(0,R)N(0,R) with R=2IR=\sigma_\epsilon^2 IR=2I.

Marginal distribution:

yN(X, V),V=ZGZ+R=s2ZZ+2I.y\sim\mathcal N\big(X\beta,\ V\big),\qquad V = ZGZ^\top + R = \sigma_s^2 Z Z^\top + \sigma_\epsilon^2 I.yN(X, V),V=ZGZ+R=s2ZZ+2I.

Variance of an observation

For any observation yijky_{ijk}yijk,

Var(yijk)=s2+2,\operatorname{Var}(y_{ijk})=\sigma_s^2+\sigma_\epsilon^2,Var(yijk)=s2+2,

and for two observations from the same subject (but different i/j),

Cov(yijk,yijk)=s2.\operatorname{Cov}(y_{ijk},y_{i'j'k})=\sigma_s^2.Cov(yijk,yijk)=s2.

So observations from the same subject are correlated (exchangeable correlation).

Best linear unbiased estimators / predictors (Henderson mixed model equations)

The mixed model equations (for known variance components) are

(XR1XXR1ZZR1XZR1Z+G1)(^u^)=(XR1yZR1y).\begin{pmatrix} X^\top R^{-1} X & X^\top R^{-1} Z\\[4pt] Z^\top R^{-1} X & Z^\top R^{-1} Z + G^{-1} \end{pmatrix} \begin{pmatrix}\hat\beta\\ \hat u\end{pmatrix} = \begin{pmatrix}X^\top R^{-1} y\\ Z^\top R^{-1} y\end{pmatrix}.(XR1XZR1XXR1ZZR1Z+G1)(^u^)=(XR1yZR1y).

With R=2IR=\sigma_\epsilon^2 IR=2I, G=s2IG=\sigma_s^2 IG=s2I, simplify accordingly. The solution gives ^\hat\beta^ (BLUE) and u^\hat uu^ (BLUP).

A practical closed-form intuition for the BLUP of a subject intercept (if each subject has nkn_knk observations) is a shrinkage estimator:

s^k=s2s2+2/nk(ykpredicted fixed mean for subject k),\widehat{s}_k = \frac{\sigma_s^2}{\sigma_s^2 + \sigma_\epsilon^2/n_k}\big(\bar y_{\cdot\cdot k} - \text{predicted fixed mean for subject }k\big),sk=s2+2/nks2(ykpredicted fixed mean for subject k),

which interpolates between the subject mean and 0 depending on signal vs noise.

Estimation of variance components and fixed effects

  • Use REML to estimate s2,2\sigma_s^2,\sigma_\epsilon^2s2,2 (REML is preferred to ML for variance components, especially with small sample or unbalanced designs).

  • Given variance components, use the mixed model equations to get ^\hat\beta^ and BLUPs u^\hat uu^.

  • Software: lme4 (R), nlme (R), SAS PROC MIXED, statsmodels (Python), etc.

Hypothesis testing / inference

  • Test fixed effects (e.g., a1=0a_1=0a1=0, a12=0a_{12}=0a12=0):

    • For large samples, Wald t/z tests on ^\hat\beta^ are common.

    • For small/unbalanced designs, use likelihood ratio tests (LRT) comparing REML fits only for nested models with the same fixed effects (or use ML fits when comparing fixed effects). LRT for variance components has boundary issues p-values are conservative unless using mixture or parametric bootstrap.

    • KenwardRoger or Satterthwaite approximations for degrees of freedom (packages: pbkrtest or lmerTest in R) provide better small-sample inference.

  • To test interaction a12a_{12}a12: compare full model vs model with a12a_{12}a12 removed (use ML when comparing fixed effect structures, or parametric bootstrap).

Coding / identifiability / interpretation

  • Your x1i,x2jx_{1i},x_{2j}x1i,x2j must be defined clearly:

    • If X1X_1X1 and X2X_2X2 are categorical factors, choose a contrast (dummy/treatment coding, sum-to-zero, orthogonal polynomial if ordered).

    • For interpretability of \mu, center numerical encodings (e.g., grand mean centering or use sum coding) so \mu is interpretable as overall mean.

    • Sum-to-zero (effects) coding makes main effects interpretable as average effect across levels; treatment coding makes coefficients comparisons versus a reference level.

  • If x1ix_{1i}x1i and x2jx_{2j}x2j are continuous covariates, include them as such (and consider centering to reduce correlation with the intercept).

  • Be careful about aliasing: if you include fixed effects that are collinear (e.g., overparameterized interactions), you need identifiability constraints.

Extension to three factors

Add a third factor X3X_3X3 with encoding x3x_{3\ell}x3 and interactions:

yijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a3x3+a12x1ix2j+a13x1ix3+a23x2jx3+a123x1ix2jx3+.y_{ijk\ell}=\mu + s_k + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_3 x_{3\ell} + a_{12} x_{1i}x_{2j} + a_{13} x_{1i}x_{3\ell}+ a_{23} x_{2j}x_{3\ell} + a_{123}x_{1i}x_{2j}x_{3\ell} + \epsilon.yijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a3x3+a12x1ix2j+a13x1ix3+a23x2jx3+a123x1ix2jx3+.

Same mixed model machinery and matrices; fixed-effect vector grows to include all main effects and interactions you choose to include.

Model diagnostics and checks

  • Check residuals vs fitted values for heteroskedasticity or patterns.

  • Check normality of residuals and (separately) of random effects (QQ plots).

  • Check random effect BLUPs for outliers.

  • If residual variance differs across groups, consider modeling heteroskedastic residuals (e.g., variance functions in nlme).

  • If correlation within subject is more complex than exchangeable (e.g., time series structure), consider random slopes or correlation structures.

Practical recommendations

  • Use REML for estimation and ML only when comparing fixed-effect structures via LRTs (then compare ML fits).

  • Center or use sum coding for factors to make the intercept meaningful.

  • If interaction is not significant and not of scientific interest, remove it for parsimony but be cautious: removing interactions changes interpretation of main effects.

  • For unbalanced designs, rely on mixed-model estimation (lmer/REML) instead of classical balanced-ANOVA formulae.

Example R (lme4) code

r
library(lme4)

# Suppose data frame df with columns:
# y, subject (factor), x1 (factor or numeric), x2 (factor or numeric)
# For categorical x1/x2 you might want sum coding:
# contrasts(df$x1) <- contr.sum(levels(df$x1)); contrasts(df$x2) <- contr.sum(levels(df$x2))

# Fit model with random intercept for subject:
m <- lmer(y ~ x1 * x2 + (1 | subject), data = df, REML = TRUE)

# Summary:
summary(m)

# Test interaction with ML comparison (fit with REML=FALSE for fixed-effect comparisons):
m_ml_full  <- lmer(y ~ x1 * x2 + (1 | subject), data = df, REML = FALSE)
m_ml_noint <- lmer(y ~ x1 + x2 + (1 | subject), data = df, REML = FALSE)
anova(m_ml_noint, m_ml_full)  # LRT for interaction (use with caution; consider parametric bootstrap)

# Kenward-Roger / p-values: lmerTest
library(lmerTest)
m_lr <- lmer(y ~ x1 * x2 + (1 | subject), data = df, REML = TRUE)
anova(m_lr)  # provides p-values with Satterthwaite df approx

Example interpretation pointers

  • If a12a_{12}a12 (coefficient on x1x2x_{1}x_{2}x1x2) is nonzero, the effect of X1X_1X1 depends on the level/value of X2X_2X2 (and vice versa).

  • s2\sigma_s^2s2 quantifies how much subjects differ from the grand mean after accounting for fixed effects.

  • Intraclass correlation (ICC) for this model (exchangeable within-subject correlation) is

    ICC=s2s2+2.\text{ICC} = \frac{\sigma_s^2}{\sigma_s^2 + \sigma_\epsilon^2}.ICC=s2+2s2.

Short checklist to run in practice

  1. Decide how to encode x1,x2x_1,x_2x1,x2 (categorical? numeric? center/contrast?).

  2. Fit full model with random subject intercept via REML.

  3. Check residuals and BLUPs.

  4. If testing fixed effects, use appropriate comparison (ML for model selection among fixed-effect structures, or parametric bootstrap / KenwardRoger for p-values).

  5. Report estimates ^\hat\beta^, ^s2\widehat{\sigma}_s^2s2, ^2\widehat{\sigma}_\epsilon^22, ICC, and effect sizes / confidence intervals.

You said:
I want to generate populations for computer simulation where we vary the effects a1 and a2. I want it for normal distributions but also for the exponential and the Poisson distribution, using a generalized linear model. How to do?
ChatGPT said:

Nice lets do this end-to-end. Ill show the general idea, exact parameterisations (so nothing ambiguous), and working R and Python code you can drop into a simulation pipeline that sweeps over values of a1a_1a1 and a2a_2a2. The same linear predictor is used for all three outcome types; only the sampling step changes.

1) Model / linear predictor (common to all)

For each simulated observation use the same linear predictor

ijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j,\eta_{ijk} = \mu + s_k + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12}\,x_{1i}x_{2j},ijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j,

where

  • skN(0,s2)s_k\sim\mathcal N(0,\sigma_s^2)skN(0,s2) is the subject random intercept,

  • x1i,x2jx_{1i},x_{2j}x1i,x2j are the encodings (numeric or dummy) for factor levels,

  • a1,a2,a12a_1,a_2,a_{12}a1,a2,a12 are fixed-effect coefficients you will vary.

Define the response mean y\mu_yy depending on family (so link functions are consistent):

  • Gaussian (identity link): y=\mu_y = \etay=. Sample yN(y,2)y \sim \mathcal N(\mu_y,\sigma_\epsilon^2)yN(y,2).

  • Poisson (log link): y=exp()\mu_y = \exp(\eta)y=exp(). Sample yPoisson(y)y \sim \mathrm{Poisson}(\mu_y)yPoisson(y).

  • Exponential (use mean parameterization with log link): choose y=exp()\mu_y=\exp(\eta)y=exp() to keep the same link as Poisson (log link). Then the Exponential rate === 1/y1/\mu_y1/y. Sample yExponential(rate=1/y)y \sim \mathrm{Exponential}(\text{rate}=1/\mu_y)yExponential(rate=1/y). (Equivalently treat exponential as Gamma with shape=1 and mean y\mu_yy.)

Notes:

  • Using the random intercept on the linear predictor for Poisson/Exponential means the subject effect is multiplicative on the mean (since exp(+sk+)=exp(sk)exp(+)\exp(\mu+s_k+\dots)=\exp(s_k)\times\exp(\mu+\dots)exp(+sk+)=exp(sk)exp(+)).

  • You can include a12a_{12}a12 or set it to zero if not interested in interaction.

2) How to vary a1,a2a_1, a_2a1,a2

Create a grid of values for a1a_1a1 and a2a_2a2 (e.g. seq(-1,1,by=0.25) or any range). For each (a1,a2) pair generate a population / repeat R simulation replicates per cell to get Monte Carlo error.

3) Working R code (simulate datasets and quick fits)

This R code:

  • simulates categorical x1,x2 with given level encodings (here I show numeric contrasts / sum coding example),

  • produces datasets for Gaussian, Poisson and Exponential,

  • shows how to fit models (lmer for Gaussian, glmer for Poisson, glmmTMB for Exponential/Gamma).

r
# REQUIRED PACKAGES
install.packages(c("lme4","glmmTMB")) # run once
library(lme4)
library(glmmTMB)

set.seed(123)

simulate_one <- function(m1=2, m2=2, n_subjects=50, n_per_cell=5,
                         mu=0, a1=0.5, a2=0.5, a12=0,
                         sigma_s = 0.5, sigma_eps = 1,
                         family = c("gaussian","poisson","exponential")) {
  family <- match.arg(family)
  
  # create factor levels and encodings
  x1_levels <- paste0("L", 1:m1)
  x2_levels <- paste0("M", 1:m2)
  # for simplicity, use numeric encodings  -1, +1 when m=2 (sum coding),
  # or equally spaced integers if more levels
  enc1 <- if (m1==2) c(-1,1) else seq(-(m1-1)/2,(m1-1)/2,length.out=m1)
  enc2 <- if (m2==2) c(-1,1) else seq(-(m2-1)/2,(m2-1)/2,length.out=m2)
  df <- expand.grid(x1 = x1_levels, x2 = x2_levels, subject = paste0("S", 1:n_subjects),
                    rep = 1:n_per_cell, KEEP.OUT.ATTRS = FALSE, stringsAsFactors = FALSE)
  # assign numeric encodings
  df$x1_num <- enc1[match(df$x1, x1_levels)]
  df$x2_num <- enc2[match(df$x2, x2_levels)]
  
  # each subject will appear in all cells? if not, you can sample allocation.
  # Here we'll allocate each subject to all combinations (balanced)
  # Expand across subjects properly:
  df <- df[order(df$subject, df$x1, df$x2, df$rep), ]
  
  # random intercept per subject
  subj_ids <- unique(df$subject)
  s_vals <- rnorm(length(subj_ids), 0, sigma_s)
  names(s_vals) <- subj_ids
  df$s_k <- s_vals[df$subject]
  
  # linear predictor
  df$eta <- mu + df$s_k + a1 * df$x1_num + a2 * df$x2_num + a12 * (df$x1_num * df$x2_num)
  
  # sample outcomes
  if (family=="gaussian") {
    df$y <- rnorm(nrow(df), mean = df$eta, sd = sigma_eps)
  } else if (family=="poisson") {
    lambda <- exp(df$eta)        # mean
    df$y <- rpois(nrow(df), lambda = lambda)
  } else if (family=="exponential") {
    mu_y <- exp(df$eta)         # mean >0
    rate <- 1 / mu_y            # rexp uses rate
    df$y <- rexp(nrow(df), rate = rate)
  }
  return(df)
}

# Example: simulate for a1=0.5,a2=-0.25:
df_g <- simulate_one(a1 = 0.5, a2 = -0.25, family="gaussian")
df_p <- simulate_one(a1 = 0.5, a2 = -0.25, family="poisson")
df_e <- simulate_one(a1 = 0.5, a2 = -0.25, family="exponential")

# Quick fits:
m_gauss <- lmer(y ~ x1_num * x2_num + (1 | subject), data = df_g, REML = TRUE)
summary(m_gauss)

m_pois <- glmer(y ~ x1_num * x2_num + (1 | subject), data = df_p, family = poisson)
summary(m_pois)

# For Exponential use Gamma(link="log") as approximation (exponential = Gamma(shape=1)
m_exp <- glmmTMB(y ~ x1_num * x2_num + (1 | subject), data = df_e, family = Gamma(link="log"))
summary(m_exp)

Notes on R:

  • glmmTMB(..., family=Gamma(link="log")) fits a Gamma GLMM with log link; exponential is Gamma with shape=1, but fitting the Gamma family with log link is a straightforward way to model positive continuous outcomes with multiplicative effects. If you need the exact exponential distribution and mixed effects, consider specialized survival frailty models (more complex).

  • Make sure encodings x1_num and x2_num match the effect scale you want. I used sum/contrast-like numeric encodings so a1 and a2 are interpretable as deviations from grand mean.

4) Working Python code (numpy / pandas; use statsmodels for basic fits, and pymer4 / statsmodels or glmmTMB equivalents for mixed GLMMs)

Below is Python for generation. Fitting GLMMs in Python is more limited; statsmodels has MixedLM for Gaussian; for Poisson GLMM use statsmodels GeneralizedLinearMixedModel (experimental) or use rpy2 to call R; alternatively use pymer4 (wrapper around lme4). Here I show generation and a Gaussian fit with statsmodels.

python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import statsmodels.api as sm
import statsmodels.formula.api as smf

def simulate_one_py(m1=2, m2=2, n_subjects=50, n_per_cell=5,
                    mu=0, a1=0.5, a2=0.5, a12=0,
                    sigma_s=0.5, sigma_eps=1,
                    family='gaussian', seed=None):
    if seed is not None:
        np.random.seed(seed)
    x1_levels = [f"L{i+1}" for i in range(m1)]
    x2_levels = [f"M{j+1}" for j in range(m2)]
    if m1==2:
        enc1 = np.array([-1,1])
    else:
        enc1 = np.linspace(-(m1-1)/2,(m1-1)/2,m1)
    if m2==2:
        enc2 = np.array([-1,1])
    else:
        enc2 = np.linspace(-(m2-1)/2,(m2-1)/2,m2)
    rows = []
    for s in range(1, n_subjects+1):
        for i,x1 in enumerate(x1_levels):
            for j,x2 in enumerate(x2_levels):
                for r in range(n_per_cell):
                    rows.append({'subject':f"S{s}", 'x1':x1, 'x2':x2,
                                 'x1_num':enc1[i], 'x2_num':enc2[j]})
    df = pd.DataFrame(rows)
    subj_unique = df['subject'].unique()
    s_vals = np.random.normal(0, sigma_s, size=len(subj_unique))
    s_map = dict(zip(subj_unique, s_vals))
    df['s_k'] = df['subject'].map(s_map)
    df['eta'] = mu + df['s_k'] + a1 * df['x1_num'] + a2 * df['x2_num'] + a12 * (df['x1_num']*df['x2_num'])
    if family=='gaussian':
        df['y'] = np.random.normal(df['eta'], sigma_eps)
    elif family=='poisson':
        lam = np.exp(df['eta'])
        # clip large lambdas to avoid overflow in practice
        lam = np.minimum(lam, 1e6)
        df['y'] = np.random.poisson(lam)
    elif family=='exponential':
        mu_y = np.exp(df['eta'])
        rate = 1.0 / mu_y
        df['y'] = np.random.exponential(1.0/rate) # numpy uses scale=1/rate
    return df

# Example simulate and fit linear mixed for gaussian outcome using statsmodels:
dfg = simulate_one_py(a1=0.6, a2=-0.3, family='gaussian', seed=1)
# statsmodels MixedLM expects endog and exog:
md = smf.mixedlm("y ~ x1_num * x2_num", dfg, groups=dfg["subject"])
mdf = md.fit(reml=True)
print(mdf.summary())

Notes on Python:

  • For Poisson/Exponential GLMM fitting you may need statsmodels experimental BinomialBayesMixedGLM or GLM for marginal models, or call R (lme4/glmmTMB) from Python with rpy2.

5) Practical tips & pitfalls

  • Scale of a1/a2: Because Poisson and Exponential use exp()\exp(\eta)exp() for the mean, coefficients are on the log scale. Changing a1a_1a1 by +1 multiplies the mean by exp(1)2.72\exp(1)\approx2.72exp(1)2.72. So choose coefficient ranges that produce realistic mean values (avoid huge ).

  • Overflow: When \eta is large positive, exp()\exp(\eta)exp() can overflow. Clip or choose coefficient magnitudes appropriately.

  • Random intercept variance: For Poisson/Exponential, moderate s\sigma_ss on the log scale implies large multiplicative subject heterogeneity; choose s\sigma_ss with thought.

  • Balanced vs unbalanced designs: my examples produce balanced data. If you want random subject assignment or missing cells, sample allocations accordingly.

  • Replicates: simulate many Monte Carlo replicates per (a1,a2) cell to estimate power, bias, MSE, coverage, etc.

  • Fitting exponential: If you want exact exponential mixed model inference, specialized frailty models exist (R: coxme, frailty), but modeling positive continuous outcomes with Gamma(link="log") in glmmTMB is a practical approach consistent with a log link.

  • Model checking: when fitting GLMMs check for convergence and overdispersion for Poisson (use Negative Binomial if needed).

6) Example simulation sweep (pseudocode)

Algorithm:

  1. choose grid A1 = {a1_1,...}, A2 = {a2_1,...}

  2. for each (a1,a2) in grid:

    • repeat R times:

      • simulate dataset for desired family

      • fit the model you will use in analysis

      • save estimates, SEs, p-values, convergence flag

  3. summarize across replicates (mean estimate, bias, RMSE, power etc.)

7) Quick numeric guidance for choosing coefficient ranges

  • If baseline mean exp()\exp(\mu)exp() is e.g. 2 (Poisson), then a coefficient a=log(1.5)0.405a= \log(1.5)\approx 0.405a=log(1.5)0.405 corresponds to a 50% increase in mean when x changes by one coding unit.

  • For exponential/Gamma with log link the same interpretation applies to the mean.

  • generate a small set of full simulation results for a user-specified grid of a1,a2a_1,a_2a1,a2 (e.g. a1 in {-0.5,0,0.5}, a2 in {-0.5,0,0.5}) and show estimated bias/power for Gaussian/Poisson/Exponential, or

  • adapt code to your exact factor encodings (categorical levels, continuous covariates), sample sizes, or desired ranges for the coefficients.

You said:
i'm interested in R and balanced designs. Is there a way (if there is) to start my simulation by producing my samples as normal (this is my latent space), and then transform to exponential or Poisson through transformation? (e.g. using pnorm functions?)
ChatGPT said:

Yes you can start from a latent normal variable and then transform it to produce Gaussian, Exponential, or Poisson outcomes.
But: it works differently for continuous (exponential, gamma, lognormal) vs count (Poisson) distributions.
Below is the clean, simulation-safe way to do it in R, for balanced designs, using your linear predictor and a latent normal variable.

1. Latent-normal approach: general principle

Start with the mixed model linear predictor

ijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j.\eta_{ijk} = \mu + s_k + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12} x_{1i}x_{2j}.ijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j.

Then generate a latent Gaussian variable

Zijk=ijk+ijk,ijkN(0,2).Z_{ijk} = \eta_{ijk} + \epsilon_{ijk},\qquad \epsilon_{ijk}\sim N(0,\sigma_\epsilon^2).Zijk=ijk+ijk,ijkN(0,2).

Then:

Outcome familyHow to obtain it from the latent normal?
GaussianY=ZY = ZY=Z directly (identity link).
ExponentialUse inverse CDF: U=(Z)U = \Phi(Z)U=(Z), then Y=log(1U)/Y = -\log(1-U) / \lambdaY=log(1U)/.
PoissonYou cannot directly transform a latent Gaussian into a Poisson count via a simple monotone transform but you can use latent normal to generate and then draw Poisson counts:
=exp(Z) \lambda = \exp(Z)=exp(Z), then YPoisson()Y\sim\text{Poisson}(\lambda)YPoisson().

This is the standard latent variable construction used by GLMMs.

2. Why Poisson cannot be obtained by direct CDF transform of a normal?

Poisson is discrete.
If you did:

r
U <- pnorm(Z)
Y <- qpois(U, lambda = ???)

you must specify a single fixed Poisson but in your model the varies by predictors and random effects:

ijk=exp(ijk).\lambda_{ijk} = \exp(\eta_{ijk}).ijk=exp(ijk).

Therefore quantile-based transformation cannot produce predictor-dependent unless you already computed from .
So the correct latent approach is:

Z=exp()YPoisson().Z \to \eta \to \lambda=\exp(\eta) \to Y\sim\text{Poisson}(\lambda).Z=exp()YPoisson().

This is consistent with GLMM theory.

3. The correct transformation method (Gaussian Exponential)

Use:

U=(Z),Y=FExp1(U),U=\Phi(Z),\quad Y = F^{-1}_{\text{Exp}}(U),U=(Z),Y=FExp1(U),

where for an exponential with rate = 1/mean:

FExp1(u)=log(1u)mean.F^{-1}_{\text{Exp}}(u) = -\log(1-u) \cdot \text{mean}.FExp1(u)=log(1u)mean.

If you want the exponential mean to follow the GLM log link:

meanijk=exp(ijk).\text{mean}_{ijk} = \exp(\eta_{ijk}).meanijk=exp(ijk).

Then:

r
U  <- pnorm(Z)
Yexp <- -log(1 - U) * exp(eta)

This gives you an exponential whose mean depends on your model.

4. Balanced R simulation template using latent normal (Gaussian / Exponential / Poisson)

Below is clean R code that:

  • creates a balanced design,

  • generates latent Z using your mixed-effects model,

  • transforms to three outcome families.

r
simulate_latent_based <- function(
  m1=2, m2=2, n_subjects=30, n_per_cell=5,
  mu=0, a1=0.5, a2=0.2, a12=0,
  sigma_s=0.5, sigma_eps=1)
{
  # Balanced design
  df <- expand.grid(
    subject = factor(1:n_subjects),
    x1 = factor(1:m1),
    x2 = factor(1:m2),
    rep = 1:n_per_cell
  )
  
  # numeric codes for effects (sum or centered)
  enc1 <- if (m1 == 2) c(-1,1) else seq(-(m1-1)/2, (m1-1)/2, length.out=m1)
  enc2 <- if (m2 == 2) c(-1,1) else seq(-(m2-1)/2, (m2-1)/2, length.out=m2)
  df$x1_num <- enc1[df$x1]
  df$x2_num <- enc2[df$x2]
  
  # random effects
  s_k <- rnorm(n_subjects, 0, sigma_s)
  df$s_k <- s_k[df$subject]
  
  # linear predictor
  df$eta <- mu + df$s_k +
    a1*df$x1_num + a2*df$x2_num + a12*(df$x1_num * df$x2_num)
  
  # latent normal variable
  df$Z <- df$eta + rnorm(nrow(df), 0, sigma_eps)
  
  # OUTCOMES:
  # Gaussian
  df$Y_g <- df$Z
  
  # Exponential via inverse CDF transform of normal
  U <- pnorm(df$Z)
  df$Y_exp <- -log(1 - U) * exp(df$eta)   # mean = exp(eta)
  
  # Poisson via  = exp(Z)
  lambda <- exp(df$Z)
  df$Y_pois <- rpois(nrow(df), lambda)
  
  df
}

# Example:
df <- simulate_latent_based()
head(df)

This gives you three parallel outcomes generated from the same latent structure.

5. Summary yes, you can use latent normal, with rules:

FamilyOK to get from latent normal?How
Gaussian YesIdentity: Y=ZY = ZY=Z.
Exponential YesInverse-CDF: U=(Z), Y=log(1U)exp()U=\Phi(Z),\ Y=-\log(1-U)\cdot \exp(\eta)U=(Z), Y=log(1U)exp().
Poisson Yes (but not via simple CDF transform)Use = exp(Z), then Poisson().

ChatGPT said:

Here is a clean, minimal R function that generates ONLY exponential outcomes using a latent normal mixed-effects model, exactly following your setup.

It uses:

  • balanced design,

  • linear predictor with random subject intercept,

  • latent normal variable

  • Exponential outcome via inverse CDF transform with mean = exp().

Clean R code exponential-only simulation

r
simulate_exponential <- function(
  m1 = 2, m2 = 2, 
  n_subjects = 30, n_per_cell = 5,
  mu = 0, a1 = 0.5, a2 = 0.2, a12 = 0,
  sigma_s = 0.5, sigma_eps = 1
) {
  # Balanced design
  df <- expand.grid(
    subject = factor(1:n_subjects),
    x1 = factor(1:m1),
    x2 = factor(1:m2),
    rep = 1:n_per_cell
  )

  # Numeric encodings for effects (sum/contrast style)
  enc1 <- if (m1 == 2) c(-1, 1) else seq(-(m1-1)/2, (m1-1)/2, length.out = m1)
  enc2 <- if (m2 == 2) c(-1, 1) else seq(-(m2-1)/2, (m2-1)/2, length.out = m2)

  df$x1_num <- enc1[df$x1]
  df$x2_num <- enc2[df$x2]

  # Random subject intercepts
  s_k <- rnorm(n_subjects, 0, sigma_s)
  df$s_k <- s_k[df$subject]

  # Linear predictor
  df$eta <- mu + df$s_k +
    a1 * df$x1_num + 
    a2 * df$x2_num + 
    a12 * (df$x1_num * df$x2_num)

  # Latent normal variable
  Z <- df$eta + rnorm(nrow(df), 0, sigma_eps)

  # Exponential outcome via inverse CDF transform
  U <- pnorm(Z)
  df$Y_exp <- -log(1 - U) * exp(df$eta)   # mean = exp(eta)

  return(df)
}

# Example:
df <- simulate_exponential()
head(df)

What this does

  • Builds a balanced design for factors X and X.

  • Constructs using fixed effects + random effects.

  • Generates latent normal values ZN(,2)Z \sim N(\eta,\sigma_\epsilon^2)ZN(,2).

  • Applies

    U=(Z),Y=log(1U)exp()U = \Phi(Z),\qquad Y = -\log(1-U)\cdot \exp(\eta)U=(Z),Y=log(1U)exp()

    to create an Exponential distribution with mean = exp().

  • Returns a data frame ready for model fitting.

You said:
how do i check if the created distributions are exponential, as with qqnorm for normal?
ChatGPT said:

To check whether your simulated outcomes really follow an exponential distribution, the direct analogue of qqnorm() for normal data is an exponential QQ-plot.

R does not have a built-in qqexp(), but you can do it using:

  • qqplot()

  • with theoretical exponential quantiles from qexp()

  • using your estimated rate/mean.

Below is the clean method.

1. Exponential QQ-plot (the correct analogue of qqnorm)

For an exponential distribution with mean = m, the theoretical quantile is:

Q(p)=mlog(1p)Q(p) = -m \log(1 - p)Q(p)=mlog(1p)

In R:

r
# y is your simulated exponential vector
y <- df$Y_exp

# Estimate mean used in exponential theorem
mhat <- mean(y)        # or use exp(eta) if known

# QQ-plot
n <- length(y)
p <- (1:n - 0.5) / n   # plotting positions
theoretical <- qexp(p, rate = 1/mhat)

plot(theoretical, sort(y),
     xlab = "Theoretical Exponential Quantiles",
     ylab = "Sample Quantiles",
     main = "Exponential QQ-Plot")
abline(0, 1, col = "red", lwd = 2)

If the points lie on a straight line data look exponential.

2. Built-in shortcut: use EnvStats::qeplot() (Easy!)

The EnvStats package includes a built-in exponential QQ plot:

r
install.packages("EnvStats")
library(EnvStats)

qeplot(y)    # automatic exponential QQ-plot

This is the closest to qqnorm() but for the exponential distribution.

3. Check via log-transform (very useful sanity check)

If YYY is exponential(), then:

log(Y)=log(U)/NOT normal\log(Y) = -\log(U)/\lambda \quad\Rightarrow\quad \text{NOT normal}log(Y)=log(U)/NOT normal

But for our latent-normal construction, the exponential is:

Y=log(1(Z))exp()Y = -\log(1 - \Phi(Z)) \cdot \exp(\eta)Y=log(1(Z))exp()

Because of the inverse-CDF transform, log(Y) minus the predictor part should relate linearly to Z, but log(Y) itself is not normal.
So this check is not as clean as the QQ-plot above but can detect coding bugs.

4. Empirical distribution fitting check (optional)

r
fit <- fitdistrplus::fitdist(y, "exp")
plot(fit)

This produces:

  • density comparison

  • CDF comparison

  • QQ plot

  • PP plot

Very useful for checking your simulated distributions.

Install package first:

r
install.packages("fitdistrplus")
library(fitdistrplus)

5. Quick wrapper function for convenience

Heres a helper you can reuse:

r
exp_qqplot <- function(y, main = "Exponential QQ-Plot") {
  y <- sort(y)
  n <- length(y)
  p <- (1:n - 0.5) / n
  mhat <- mean(y)
  theo <- qexp(p, rate = 1/mhat)
  
  plot(theo, y,
       xlab = "Theoretical Quantiles",
       ylab = "Sample Quantiles",
       main = main)
  abline(0, 1, col = "red", lwd = 2)
}

Use:

r
exp_qqplot(df$Y_exp)

Interpretation

Good fit = points close to straight line.
Curvature indicates mismatch:

  • concave upward heavier-tailed than exponential

  • concave downward lighter-tailed

  • S-shaped mixture or mis-specified rate

i have a question for the U <- pnorm(Z) and then for the df$Y_exp <- -log(1 - U) * exp(df$eta) If a1 = 4 and a2 = 0 and a12 = 0. The Z will be the combination of two normal distributions (separated by a1), right? Now the -log(1 - U) alone will also produce a combination of two distinct distributions. But are these exponential? And why do we need to also multiply by exp(eta)?
ChatGPT said:

Great questions these go right to the heart of why the inverse-CDF method works and what happens when you introduce structure (effects a, a, ) into the latent variable.

Lets go carefully, step by step.

1. When a = 4, a = 0, a = 0 what does Z look like?

The linear predictor is:

=+sk+a1x1i\eta = \mu + s_k + a_1 x_{1i}=+sk+a1x1i

If you use 1 encoding for x, then:

  • Level 1 of X = + s_k 4

  • Level 2 of X = + s_k + 4

So Z is:

Z=+,N(0,2)Z = \eta + \epsilon,\quad \epsilon \sim N(0, \sigma_\epsilon^2)Z=+,N(0,2)

This means:

  • Two well-separated normal distributions, one centered at = 4, one at +4
    (plus random subject intercepts, which smear it slightly)

You are correct!

2. What does U=(Z)U = \Phi(Z)U=(Z) look like?

Since is monotonically increasing, two separated normal groups in Z become two separated groups in U.

Each group is:

U=(Z)=FN(Z)U = \Phi(Z) = F_N(Z)U=(Z)=FN(Z)

This produces something bounded between 0 and 1 but still clearly two clusters:

  • near 0 for the group with lower Z

  • near 1 for the group with higher Z

3. Is log(1 U) exponential?

Yes log(1 U) is exponential if and only if:

  • U is Uniform(0,1)

But here, U is not uniform.
It is the CDF of a shifted normal mixture.

So:

log(1 U) is not exponential

It is two different exponential-like shapes, but they are not exponential with a common rate.

This is a crucial insight.

4. So how do we recover a proper exponential distribution?

This is the reason we multiply by exp().

KEY POINT

The goal is to simulate a generalized linear model:

YExponential(mean=Y)Y \sim \text{Exponential}(\text{mean} = \mu_Y)YExponential(mean=Y)

with link function:

Y=exp()\mu_Y = \exp(\eta)Y=exp()

So we want:

YExponential(mean=exp())Y \mid \eta \sim \text{Exponential}(\text{mean}=\exp(\eta))YExponential(mean=exp())

The correct inverse-CDF sampler for such an exponential is:

Y=log(1U)exp()Y = -\log(1 - U) \cdot \exp(\eta)Y=log(1U)exp()

This works if and only if:

  • U is uniform, independent of .

But in your model, U is not uniform!

Correct and this is why:

Your current U = (Z) construction does not produce the correct GLM exponential distribution unless Z is unconditional standard normal.

Your Z instead contains fixed effects, random intercepts, and main effects, so U is not uniform.

Thus:

You do NOT get a true exponential GLM distribution by using Z U exponential.

This is the conceptual mistake.

What is the correct way to simulate GLM exponential responses?

Use the normal linear predictor only to compute the mean:

Y=exp()\mu_Y = \exp(\eta)Y=exp()

Then draw:

YExponential(rate=1/Y)Y \sim \text{Exponential}(\text{rate} = 1/\mu_Y)YExponential(rate=1/Y)

In R:

r
lambda <- 1 / exp(df$eta)
df$Y_exp <- rexp(nrow(df), rate = lambda)

This is the proper GLM simulation.

Then what was the latent normal model doing?

Your earlier idea tries to:

  • start with a latent normal model

  • transform it to exponential

But this only works if:

  • Z N(0,1) with no predictors

  • Use U = (Z)

  • Then apply inverse-CDF of exponential.

As soon as shifts Z, U is no longer uniform, and the exponential is distorted.

Final answers to your questions

Q1: Are the two clusters exponential?

No. They become mixtures of exponentials, not exponential.

Q2: Why multiply by exp()?

Because GLMs require:

E[Y]=exp()\mathbb{E}[Y\mid \eta] = \exp(\eta)E[Y]=exp()

But this is only valid if U is uniform which it is not in the latent-normal approach.

Q3: Is the latent-normal method appropriate for simulating GLMs?

No.
If you want real exponential GLM distributions, do not use the latent normal pnorm inverse-CDF trick.

Use:

r
mu <- exp(df$eta)
df$Y_exp <- rexp(nrow(df), rate = 1 / mu)

You said:
If it still possible to have a corrected version of the latent-normal model in a way that it makes sense, I want to see it.
ChatGPT said:

Yes there is a sensible corrected latent-normal construction. The key is to be explicit about what the latent normal is modeling and what is actually exponential.

Below I give two clean, principled variants and runnable R code for each, plus diagnostics that show whether the exponential assumption holds conditionally. The single most useful diagnostic is the probability integral transform for the conditional exponential: if YExp(mean=)Y\mid\mu\sim\mathrm{Exp}(\text{mean}=\mu)YExp(mean=), then

U=1exp(Y/)  Uniform(0,1).U = 1 - \exp\!\big(-Y/\mu\big)\ \sim\ \text{Uniform}(0,1).U=1exp(Y/)  Uniform(0,1).

You can QQ-plot those UUU's against Uniform(0,1) (or use the same idea grouped by factor levels).

Variant A The correct GLMM (random intercept on log-mean)

This is the canonical way to combine a normal latent effect and an exponential outcome in a GLMM:

  • Linear predictor (subject-level random intercept):

    ijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j,skN(0,s2).\eta_{ijk}=\mu + s_k + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12} x_{1i}x_{2j}, \quad s_k\sim N(0,\sigma_s^2).ijk=+sk+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j,skN(0,s2).

  • Mean on the response scale:

    ijk=exp(ijk).\mu_{ijk}=\exp(\eta_{ijk}).ijk=exp(ijk).

  • Data generation:

    YijkskExponential(mean=ijk),Y_{ijk}\mid s_k \sim \text{Exponential}\big(\text{mean}=\mu_{ijk}\big),YijkskExponential(mean=ijk),

    i.e. rexp(n, rate = 1 / mu) in R.

This is a hierarchical model: conditional on s_k (and predictors) each observation is an exponential with mean exp(eta). Marginally (averaging over s_k) the distribution is a mixture of exponentials (not a single exponential) which is expected for a GLMM and what you normally want.

R code (Variant A)

r
simulate_glmm_exp <- function(
  m1 = 2, m2 = 2,
  n_subjects = 30, n_per_cell = 5,
  mu = 0, a1 = 4, a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
  sigma_s = 0.5, seed = 1
) {
  set.seed(seed)
  df <- expand.grid(
    subject = factor(1:n_subjects),
    x1 = factor(1:m1),
    x2 = factor(1:m2),
    rep = 1:n_per_cell
  )
  enc1 <- if (m1==2) c(-1,1) else seq(-(m1-1)/2,(m1-1)/2,length.out=m1)
  enc2 <- if (m2==2) c(-1,1) else seq(-(m2-1)/2,(m2-1)/2,length.out=m2)
  df$x1_num <- enc1[as.integer(df$x1)]
  df$x2_num <- enc2[as.integer(df$x2)]

  # subject random intercepts
  s_vals <- rnorm(n_subjects, 0, sigma_s)
  df$s_k <- s_vals[as.integer(df$subject)]

  # linear predictor and mean
  df$eta <- mu + df$s_k + a1*df$x1_num + a2*df$x2_num + a12*(df$x1_num*df$x2_num)
  df$mu_y <- exp(df$eta)

  # draw exponential conditional on mu_y
  df$Y <- rexp(nrow(df), rate = 1/df$mu_y)

  rownames(df) <- NULL
  df
}

# Example
dfA <- simulate_glmm_exp(a1 = 4, a2 = 0, sigma_s = 0.2)
head(dfA)

Variant B Latent log-normal mixture (per-observation multiplicative heterogeneity)

If you want extra per-observation latent noise on the log-mean (i.e. a latent normal that directly perturbs the log-mean before drawing the exponential), do this:

  • Let VijkN(0,2)V_{ijk}\sim N(0,\tau^2)VijkN(0,2) be an observation-level latent normal noise.

  • Define Zijk=ijk+VijkZ_{ijk} = \eta_{ijk} + V_{ijk}Zijk=ijk+Vijk.

  • Set ijk=exp(Zijk)\mu_{ijk}=\exp(Z_{ijk})ijk=exp(Zijk).

  • Then YijkZijkExp(mean=ijk)Y_{ijk}\mid Z_{ijk}\sim\mathrm{Exp}(\text{mean}=\mu_{ijk})YijkZijkExp(mean=ijk).

This is equivalent to saying the rate/mean is log-normal-distributed around the predictor: it produces a heavy-tailed marginal distribution for Y (a mixture of exponentials with lognormal mixing). This is a coherent latent-normal model and often used to model multiplicative overdispersion.

R code (Variant B)

r
simulate_latent_lognormal_exp <- function(
  m1 = 2, m2 = 2,
  n_subjects = 30, n_per_cell = 5,
  mu = 0, a1 = 4, a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
  sigma_s = 0.3, tau = 0.5, seed = 1
) {
  set.seed(seed)
  df <- expand.grid(
    subject = factor(1:n_subjects),
    x1 = factor(1:m1),
    x2 = factor(1:m2),
    rep = 1:n_per_cell
  )
  enc1 <- if (m1==2) c(-1,1) else seq(-(m1-1)/2,(m1-1)/2,length.out=m1)
  enc2 <- if (m2==2) c(-1,1) else seq(-(m2-1)/2,(m2-1)/2,length.out=m2)
  df$x1_num <- enc1[as.integer(df$x1)]
  df$x2_num <- enc2[as.integer(df$x2)]

  # subject intercepts
  s_vals <- rnorm(n_subjects, 0, sigma_s)
  df$s_k <- s_vals[as.integer(df$subject)]

  df$eta <- mu + df$s_k + a1*df$x1_num + a2*df$x2_num + a12*(df$x1_num*df$x2_num)

  # observation-level latent normal perturbation
  df$v <- rnorm(nrow(df), 0, tau)
  df$z <- df$eta + df$v
  df$mu_y <- exp(df$z)

  # draw exponential conditional on mu_y
  df$Y <- rexp(nrow(df), rate = 1/df$mu_y)

  df
}

# Example
dfB <- simulate_latent_lognormal_exp()
head(dfB)

Diagnostics how to check the conditional exponential assumption (the right test)

As noted above, if the model is

YExp(mean=),Y\mid \mu \sim \mathrm{Exp}(\text{mean}=\mu),YExp(mean=),

then

U=1exp(Y/)Uniform(0,1).U = 1 - \exp(-Y/\mu) \sim \text{Uniform}(0,1).U=1exp(Y/)Uniform(0,1).

So for each observation you can compute Ui=1exp(Yi/i)U_i=1-\exp(-Y_i/\mu_i)Ui=1exp(Yi/i) where mu_i is the conditional mean used to simulate (i.e. exp(eta) in Variant A or exp(z) in Variant B). Then:

  • QQ-plot U vs Uniform quantiles (or qqnorm on qnorm(U)), or

  • Kolmogorov test against punif.

If the conditional exponential draws are correct, U will look uniform. If you instead try the wrong latent pnormqexp trick you asked about earlier, U will not be uniform.

R code for diagnostics

r
# For Variant A (dfA) or Variant B (dfB), compute U and QQ plot
check_conditional_exp <- function(df, mu_col = "mu_y", y_col = "Y", main = "Uniform QQ of PIT") {
  mu <- df[[mu_col]]
  y  <- df[[y_col]]
  U <- 1 - exp(- y / mu)
  U <- pmin(pmax(U, 0), 1)   # numeric safety
  # QQ against uniform:
  n <- length(U)
  p <- (1:n - 0.5) / n
  plot(qbeta(p, 1, 1), sort(U), xlab = "Theoretical Uniform Quantiles",
       ylab = "Sample PIT Quantiles", main = main)
  abline(0, 1, col = "red", lwd = 2)
  # Return KS test too
  ks <- ks.test(U, "punif")
  list(U = U, ks = ks)
}

resA <- check_conditional_exp(dfA, mu_col = "mu_y", main = "Variant A: PIT Uniform QQ")
resA$ks

resB <- check_conditional_exp(dfB, mu_col = "mu_y", main = "Variant B: PIT Uniform QQ")
resB$ks

Interpretation:

  • If the QQ points lie on the 45 line and ks.test p-value is large, the conditional exponential model is consistent with the simulated data (as it should be if you simulated as above).

  • If not, the simulation or assumed conditional mean mu is wrong.

Visual check per-factor level (why it helps)

If a1=4 and a2=0 you can examine the distribution within each X1 level:

  • In Variant A, conditional on subject intercept s_k, observations within a fixed level and subject are exponential; if you ignore subject-level heterogeneity you will see mixtures.

  • A simple plot is to compute the PIT U using the conditional mu used to simulate each observation and then QQ-plot grouped by x1 to confirm correct conditional behavior.

Summary / Takeaways

  • The wrong trick was: take a latent Z=+Z=\eta+\epsilonZ=+, form U=(Z)U=\Phi(Z)U=(Z), and then do qexp(U) that does not yield YExp(mean=exp())Y|\eta\sim\mathrm{Exp}(\text{mean}=\exp(\eta))YExp(mean=exp()) because UUU is not uniform when Z depends on predictors.

  • Correct and principled approaches:

    • Variant A (recommended for GLMM-style simulations): make the log-mean linear in predictors and random intercepts, then draw Y ~ Exp(mean = exp(eta)).

    • Variant B (latent log-normal mixing): add per-observation normal noise on the log-mean, then draw Y ~ Exp(mean = exp(log-mean)). This yields extra heterogeneity (mixture of exponentials).

  • To check conditional exponentiality, transform each observation to U=1exp(Y/)U = 1 - \exp(-Y/\mu)U=1exp(Y/); these UUU's should be Uniform(0,1) if the conditional exponential model holds. Use QQ plots and a KS test.

You said:
Thank you. Coming back to your previous wrong latent model solution, if we were producing log-normal (not exponential) distributions, would in this case work or not? Would the CDF trick work in this case? Would the produced distribution be log-normal?
ChatGPT said:

Short answer: yes for log-normal you dont need the pnorm inverse-CDF trick. If your latent variable is normal, simply exponentiating it produces a log-normal. The CDF trick only works if you use the same CDF for the PIT as the latent distribution; using U <- pnorm(Z) and then qlnorm(U, ...) will not give you Y = exp(Z) in general unless Z is standard normal with the exact parameters you pass to qlnorm.

Below I explain precisely why, what to do instead, and give a small R demo and diagnostics.

1) Math / intuition (brief)

Let ZN(Z,Z2)Z\sim N(\mu_Z,\sigma_Z^2)ZN(Z,Z2).

  • The transformation Y=exp(Z)Y=\exp(Z)Y=exp(Z) gives YYY a log-normal distribution with parameters meanlog = _Z, sdlog = _Z.

  • The probability integral transform (PIT) says U=FZ(Z)U = F_Z(Z)U=FZ(Z) is Uniform(0,1) iff FZF_ZFZ is the CDF of ZZZ. That is, you must use the true CDF of ZZZ.

    • If you take U=(Z)U = \Phi(Z)U=(Z) (standard normal CDF) but ZZZ has mean Z0\mu_Z\neq0Z=0 or sd Z1\sigma_Z\neq1Z=1, then UUU is not uniform.

  • If you do the PIT correctly: U=FZ(Z)=((ZZ)/Z)U = F_Z(Z) = \Phi\big((Z-\mu_Z)/\sigma_Z\big)U=FZ(Z)=((ZZ)/Z), then UUniform(0,1)U\sim\text{Uniform}(0,1)UUniform(0,1). Applying any inverse CDF F_target^{-1}(U) will produce a draw from the target distribution. In particular, if you then do qlnorm(U, meanlog=_Z, sdlog=_Z) you recover the same distribution as exp(Z).

So two equivalent, correct constructions for log-normal:

A) Direct: Z ~ Normal(mu_Z, sigma_Z); Y = exp(Z).

B) PIT route (redundant but valid): U = F_Z(Z), then Y = qlnorm(U, meanlog = mu_Z, sdlog = sigma_Z).

But the shortcut U <- pnorm(Z) is only correct if Z ~ N(0,1). If Z has nonzero mean or sd 1, pnorm(Z) is wrong.

2) Practical caveats for GLM/GLMM setup

If your latent normal Z = + with ~ N(0, _^2) and depends on predictors (fixed effects and random intercepts):

  • Conditional on , Z | ~ N(, _^2).

  • Then Y = exp(Z) gives conditional log-normal:
    logYN(,2)\log Y \mid \eta \sim N(\eta,\sigma_\epsilon^2)logYN(,2).
    So Y is log-normal conditional on , which is usually exactly what you want if your latent model is a model for log-means.

  • If your modelling goal was to have conditional mean on original scale equal to exp() (i.e. E[Y|] = exp()), note:

    • For a lognormal, E[Y]=exp(+122)E[Y\mid\eta] = \exp(\eta + \tfrac12\sigma_\epsilon^2)E[Y]=exp(+212).

    • If you prefer E[Y|] = exp() exactly, simulate Z with mean - 0.5 _^2 (i.e. subtract the half-variance correction): then E[exp(Z)] = exp().

3) Short R demo (simulate and check with qqnorm of log)

r
set.seed(1)

# settings
n <- 1000
mu_eta <- 1.0      # could be eta that depends on predictors
sigma_eps <- 0.6

# latent normal
Z <- rnorm(n, mean = mu_eta, sd = sigma_eps)

# direct log-normal
Y_ln <- exp(Z)

# check: log(Y) should be normal with mean mu_eta, sd sigma_eps
qqnorm(log(Y_ln), main = "QQ: log(Y) vs Normal"); abline(0,1,col="red")
mean(log(Y_ln)); sd(log(Y_ln))

If the QQ plot is near a straight line and sample mean/sd are near mu_eta/sigma_eps, you have conditional log-normality.

4) If you tried U <- pnorm(Z) + qlnorm(U, meanlog=mu, sdlog=sigma) when does that work?

  • Works only when pnorm equals F_Z, i.e. only when Z ~ N(0,1) and you call qlnorm(U, meanlog=0, sdlog=1).

  • If Z has mean 0 or sd 1, pnorm(Z) is not the PIT; qlnorm(pnorm(Z), meanlog=_Z, sdlog=_Z) will not equal exp(Z) and will produce a distorted distribution.

If you want the PIT route to succeed, compute the correct PIT:

r
U <- pnorm((Z - mu_Z)/sigma_Z)   # true PIT -> uniform(0,1)
Y_via_pit <- qlnorm(U, meanlog = mu_Z, sdlog = sigma_Z)  # equals exp(Z)

But of course that's redundant because Y_via_pit will be exactly exp(Z).

5) Summary / recommendation

  • For log-normal: just use Y = exp(Z). That's simple, correct, and interpretable.

  • If your latent Z includes predictors (), log Y | will be normal with mean and you can model it accordingly.

  • If you want E[Y|] = exp() exactly, shift Z by -0.5 _^2: simulate Z ~ N( - 0.5 _^2, _^2) then Y = exp(Z).

  • Avoid the pnorm(Z) qlnorm() shortcut unless you prove Z is standard normal (it usually isnt).

ChatGPT said:

Nice this is behaving exactly as probability theory predicts. Short answer: your norm2lnorm() will produce true log-normal draws if and only if the input x really is (approximately) Normal with the mu and sd you pass to pnorm. When that condition holds, the PIT (U = F_X(X)) is Uniform(0,1) and F^{-1}_{\text{LogNormal}}(U) is guaranteed to have the Log-Normal distribution you asked for.

Below I explain why your code worked, the caveats (when it wont work), how to test it, and give a few small R snippets you can use.

Why your norm2lnorm() can produce log-normal-looking data

Your function:

r
norm2lnorm <- function(x, meanlog = 0, sdlog = 1, mu = mean(x), sd = sd(x), ...) {
  p <- pnorm(x, mu, sd) 
  qlnorm(p, meanlog, sdlog, ...) 
}

does this:

  1. p <- pnorm(x, mu, sd) computes Ui=FN(,)(xi)U_i = F_{N(\mu,\sigma)}(x_i)Ui=FN(,)(xi).
    If xiN(,2)x_i \sim N(\mu,\sigma^2)xiN(,2), then UiUniform(0,1)U_i\sim\mathrm{Uniform}(0,1)UiUniform(0,1) (PIT).

  2. qlnorm(p, meanlog, sdlog) maps those uniform variates to the target log-normal via the inverse CDF. By the PIT property, the output has exactly the Log-Normal(meanlog,sdlog) distribution.

So when your x actually is normal, the output is exactly log-normal (not just approximately). Thats why the log of the transformed data looks normal in QQ plots and histograms.

When it doesnt produce a true log-normal

If the distribution of x is not Normal(,), then U = pnorm(x, mu, sd) is not uniform and the transform will not produce exactly the intended log-normal distribution. Examples:

  • If x is a mixture of two normals (e.g. two groups separated by a large a1), the pooled x is not a single normal. Using global mu = mean(x) and sd = sd(x) will distort the PIT and produce something that may look log-normal in some diagnostics but is actually a transformed mixture (not exact).

  • If x has skewness/kurtosis different from normal, same issue.

That said, in many practical cases (moderate mixtures or if you standardize per group) the transform can look very close to log-normal.

How to make the mapping correct for structured data (e.g. groups / predictors)

If your latent Z has structure (e.g. Z = + with depending on X), do one of these:

A Conditional (correct) approach (recommended for GLMM-like structure)
Apply the PIT and inverse CDF within each conditional class where Z is normal. For example, if Z conditional on x1 level is Normal(_, ), compute

r
U <- pnorm(Z, mean = mu_l, sd = sd_l)   # per-level parameters
Y <- qlnorm(U, meanlog = target_meanlog, sdlog = target_sdlog)

This produces a target log-normal distribution conditional on the class you used.

B Direct exp (simpler for log-normal)
If your intended target is Y = exp(Z) with Z ~ N(, ), just do Y <- exp(Z). That is simpler and exact.

Tests / diagnostics you can run (R code)

1) Check log(Y) is Normal( meanlog, sdlog )

r
# y is the output from norm2lnorm
qqnorm(log(y)); abline(0,1,col="red")

# formal test: compare to theoretical normal
shapiro.test(log(y))        # small samples
# or check mean/sd close to target
meanlog_hat <- mean(log(y))
sdlog_hat   <- sd(log(y))
c(meanlog_hat, sdlog_hat)

2) Check PIT uniformity (general test)

If you know the underlying Z distribution parameters used in pnorm, check the PIT directly:

r
# if x ~ N(mu, sd^2) was your input
U <- pnorm(x, mean = mu, sd = sd)
qqplot(qunif(ppoints(length(U))), sort(U)); abline(0,1,col="red")
ks.test(U, "punif")   # tests uniformity

If ks.test is non-significant and QQ is straight, U is uniform and the lognormal mapping is valid.

Quick demonstration idea to convince yourself

Simulate two cases and compare:

  1. Z ~ N(0,1) then Y1 <- norm2lnorm(Z, meanlog=0, sdlog=1, mu=0, sd=1) should match exp(Z) distribution (after appropriate parameter matching).

  2. Z_mix <- c(rnorm(500,-3,1), rnorm(500, 3,1)) (a mixture). Apply your norm2lnorm(Z_mix) with global mu=mean(Z_mix) and sd=sd(Z_mix). Inspect qqnorm(log(Y)) it may look OK or hide the mixture; but PIT and KS will reveal mismatch.

Practical recommendation

  • For log-normal targets the simplest and clearest route is to generate the latent normal and exponentiate (Y = exp(Z)). If you want E[Y|] = exp(), remember the half-variance correction: simulate Z ~ N( - 0.5 ^2, ^2) so E[exp(Z)] = exp().

  • If you prefer to use PIT mapping, make sure you use the true CDF of x (not the standard pnorm unless x is standard normal). Using mu=mean(x), sd=sd(x) can work if x is indeed roughly normal with those parameters which appears to be the case in your experiments.

You said:
in your response "What is the correct way to simulate GLM exponential responses?" I do not understand why \mu_Y = exp(\eta)
ChatGPT said:

Great this is an important point, and it becomes very simple once you see the general rule of GLMs.

Let me explain exactly why

Y=exp()\mu_Y = \exp(\eta)Y=exp()

for exponential and Poisson GLMs.

1. In a GLM, the mean is linked to the linear predictor via the link function

A GLM has the form:

  • Linear predictor:

    =X\eta = X\beta=X

  • Link function:

    g()=g(\mu) = \etag()=

Therefore, the mean is:

=g1()\mu = g^{-1}(\eta)=g1()

So the question becomes:

What is the link function for the exponential distribution?

2. For the exponential distribution, we typically use the log link

An exponential distribution is defined by a rate parameter :

YExponential(),E[Y]=1Y \sim \text{Exponential}(\lambda), \qquad \mathbb{E}[Y] = \frac{1}{\lambda}YExponential(),E[Y]=1

GLMs require that the mean must be positive.
The log link guarantees positivity.

So we define:

=E[Y]>0,g()=log()\mu = \mathbb{E}[Y] > 0, \quad g(\mu) = \log(\mu)=E[Y]>0,g()=log()

Thus:

=log()=exp()\eta = \log(\mu) \quad\Rightarrow\quad \mu = \exp(\eta)=log()=exp()

This is exactly the same link function used in Poisson GLMs.

Why not model the rate directly?

We could instead link to :

  • Choice 1: model mean with log link = exp()

  • Choice 2: model rate with log link = exp(), = 1/ = exp(-)

Both are valid.

But:

Standard GLM theory always defines the link on the mean, not the rate.

So we use mean parametrization:

YExponential(),f(y)=1exp(y/)Y \sim \text{Exponential}(\mu),\qquad f(y) = \frac{1}{\mu}\exp(-y/\mu)YExponential(),f(y)=1exp(y/)

And the log link gives:

=exp()\mu = \exp(\eta)=exp()

Example: simulation in R

r
eta  <- 2 + 0.5*x1 - 0.3*x2          # linear predictor
mu   <- exp(eta)                    # GLM mean
Y    <- rexp(n, rate = 1/mu)        # exponential with mean = mu

This is the standard and correct simulation procedure.

Summary (why = exp())

  • GLMs always model the mean:

    g()=g(\mu) = \etag()=

  • Using the log link:

    =exp()\mu = \exp(\eta)=exp()

  • Exponential distributions are defined in GLMs through their mean, not the rate.

  • Ensures positivity and matches standard GLM implementation in R (glm(family=Gamma(link="log")) with shape=1).

Here is a clean, correct, general simulation template for GLM-based data generation for your balanced two-factor design covering Normal, Exponential, Poisson, Binomial, Gamma, and Cauchy, all using the correct model and link functions (or appropriate distributions if the GLM family does not exist).

This is exactly the structure you can plug into your simulations.

General GLM Simulation Template for a Balanced Two-Factor Design

Model

Your linear predictor is:

ij=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j\eta_{ij} = \mu + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12} x_{1i} x_{2j}ij=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j

Balanced design:

  • factor X1X_1X1: m1m_1m1 levels

  • factor X2X_2X2: m2m_2m2 levels

  • each cell replicated rrr times

Let N=m1m2rN = m_1 m_2 rN=m1m2r.

R Code Template (Modular & Plug-and-Play)

r
simulate_glm_data <- function(
  m1, m2, r, 
  mu = 0,
  a1 = 0, a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
  dist = c("normal", "exponential", "poisson", "binomial", "gamma", "cauchy"),
  sd_normal = 1,
  size_binom = 10,
  shape_gamma = 2
) {
  dist <- match.arg(dist)

  # ----- Balanced design -----
  X1 <- factor(rep(1:m1, each = m2 * r))
  X2 <- factor(rep(rep(1:m2, each = r), times = m1))

  # numerical coding (use your preferred coding)
  x1 <- as.numeric(X1)
  x2 <- as.numeric(X2)

  # linear predictor
  eta <- mu + a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*x1*x2

  # ----- Generate responses according to GLM -----
  Y <- switch(
    dist,

    # 1. Normal (identity link)
    normal = rnorm(length(eta), mean = eta, sd = sd_normal),

    # 2. Exponential (mean parameterization, log link)
    exponential = {
      mu_exp <- exp(eta)       # mean
      rexp(length(eta), rate = 1/mu_exp)
    },

    # 3. Poisson (log link)
    poisson = {
      lambda <- exp(eta)
      rpois(length(eta), lambda = lambda)
    },

    # 4. Binomial (logit link)
    binomial = {
      p <- plogis(eta)  # logistic inverse link
      rbinom(length(eta), size = size_binom, prob = p)
    },

    # 5. Gamma (log link)
    gamma = {
      mu_g <- exp(eta)  # mean
      rgamma(length(eta), shape = shape_gamma, scale = mu_g / shape_gamma)
    },

    # 6. Cauchy (does not fit a GLM family; simulate directly)
    cauchy = rcauchy(length(eta), location = eta, scale = 1)
  )

  data.frame(Y, X1, X2, eta)
}

How it works (and why it is correct)

1. Normal

Uses:

Y=+,N(0,2)Y = \eta + \epsilon, \quad \epsilon \sim N(0, \sigma^2)Y=+,N(0,2)

2. Exponential GLM (Gamma with shape = 1)

GLM specifies:

g()=log()==exp()g(\mu) = \log(\mu) = \eta \quad\Rightarrow\quad \mu = \exp(\eta)g()=log()==exp()

Simulation uses:

r
rexp(n, rate = 1/mu)

which is exactly Exponential(mean = ).

3. Poisson

GLM link:

=exp()\lambda = \exp(\eta)=exp()

4. Binomial

GLM link:

p=11+ep = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-\eta}}p=1+e1

5. Gamma

GLM link:

=exp()\mu = \exp(\eta)=exp()

with fixed shape.

6. Cauchy

No GLM family exists (not exponential family).
Correct approach is to simulate directly:

YijCauchy(,)Y_{ij} \sim \text{Cauchy}(\eta, \gamma)YijCauchy(,)

This is standard and legitimate.

Example usage

Simulate Exponential data with effects

r
df <- simulate_glm_data(
  m1 = 3, m2 = 2, r = 20,
  mu = 0,
  a1 = 0.4, a2 = 0.2, a12 = 0.1,
  dist = "exponential"
)

Simulate Poisson

r

Simulate Cauchy

r

1. Model with subject random intercept

Your intended model becomes:

ijk=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j+sk\eta_{ijk} = \mu + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12} x_{1i}x_{2j} + s_kijk=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j+sk

where:

  • skN(0,s2)s_k \sim N(0, \sigma_s^2)skN(0,s2)

  • subjects are indexed by k=1,,nk = 1, \ldots, nk=1,,n

  • each subject has measurements across cells (balanced, crossed).

This works exactly as in a GLMM:
the random effect simply adds into the linear predictor, and then the inverse link determines the mean.

2. GLMM meanings for each distribution

For all GLM families, we use:

Mean=g1()\text{Mean} = g^{-1}(\eta)Mean=g1()

  • Normal (identity link)
    Y=+Y = \eta + \epsilonY=+

  • Exponential (Gamma with shape = 1, log link)
    =e\mu = e^\eta=e

  • Poisson (log link)
    =e\lambda = e^\eta=e

  • Binomial (logit link)
    p=logit1()p = \text{logit}^{-1}(\eta)p=logit1()

  • Gamma (log link)

  • Cauchy (not a GLM family)

    YCauchy(location=,scale)Y \sim \text{Cauchy}(\text{location}=\eta, \text{scale})YCauchy(location=,scale)

Everything works because the random effect modifies the linear predictor.

3. Complete Simulation Function (Final Version, with Random Effect)

This function handles:

  • two factors X1, X2

  • balanced design with r replicates per cell per subject

  • n subjects, each with their own random intercept

  • all GLM distributions you need

  • one clean interface

r
simulate_glmm_data <- function(
  m1, m2, r,              # balanced factorial design
  n_subj,                 # number of subjects
  mu = 0,                 # intercept
  a1 = 0, a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
  dist = c("normal", "exponential", "poisson", "binomial", "gamma", "cauchy"),
  sd_normal = 1,
  sd_subject = 1,         # SD of random intercept (subject effect)
  size_binom = 10,
  shape_gamma = 2
) {
  dist <- match.arg(dist)

  # -----------------------------
  # Balanced design with subjects
  # -----------------------------
  total_per_subject <- m1 * m2 * r
  SUBJECT <- factor(rep(1:n_subj, each = total_per_subject))

  X1 <- factor(rep(rep(1:m1, each = m2 * r), times = n_subj))
  X2 <- factor(rep(rep(rep(1:m2, each = r), times = m1), times = n_subj))

  x1 <- as.numeric(X1)
  x2 <- as.numeric(X2)

  # -----------------------------
  # Random intercepts
  # -----------------------------
  s_k <- rnorm(n_subj, mean = 0, sd = sd_subject)
  s <- s_k[ SUBJECT ]

  # -----------------------------
  # Linear predictor
  # -----------------------------
  eta <- mu + a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*x1*x2 + s

  # -----------------------------
  # Generate responses
  # -----------------------------
  Y <- switch(
    dist,

    # Normal GLMM
    normal = rnorm(length(eta), mean = eta, sd = sd_normal),

    # Exponential GLMM (Gamma shape=1)
    exponential = {
      mu_exp <- exp(eta)
      rexp(length(eta), rate = 1/mu_exp)
    },

    # Poisson GLMM
    poisson = {
      lambda <- exp(eta)
      rpois(length(eta), lambda)
    },

    # Binomial GLMM
    binomial = {
      p <- plogis(eta)
      rbinom(length(eta), size=size_binom, prob=p)
    },

    # Gamma GLMM
    gamma = {
      mu_g <- exp(eta)
      rgamma(length(eta), shape=shape_gamma, scale = mu_g/shape_gamma)
    },

    # Cauchy (non-GLM)
    cauchy = rcauchy(length(eta), location = eta, scale = 1)
  )

  data.frame(
    SUBJECT, X1, X2,
    eta = eta,
    Y = Y
  )
}

Example Usage

Exponential GLMM with random subjects

r
df <- simulate_glmm_data(
  m1 = 3, m2 = 2, r = 10,
  n_subj = 30,
  a1 = 0.4, a2 = 0.2,
  dist = "exponential",
  sd_subject = 0.6
)

Poisson GLMM

You said:
i want in my simulation to have some control of the parameters of the target distribution so that I can test some problematic cases. For the binomial distribution for example, i want to be able to test it when probabilities are closer to 0 (such as 10%). Or even being able to have results for a variaty of probabilities such as 5% 10% and 20%. How could I do this?
ChatGPT said:

How to control target probabilities (and other distribution parameters) in simulations

Short answer:

  • For Binomial/Bernoulli (logit link) the baseline intercept mu determines the probability. If there are no random effects, set mu = logit(p_target) and you get p = p_target.

  • If you include subject random intercepts, the marginal (population-level) probability differs from the conditional (plogis(eta)) because you average over the random-effect distribution. To get a desired marginal probability (e.g. 5%, 10%, 20%) you must solve for the intercept mu that makes

    pmarginal()=logit1(+s)(s;0,s2)ds=ptarget.p_{\text{marginal}}(\mu) = \int \text{logit}^{-1}(\mu + s)\,\phi(s;0,\sigma_s^2)\,ds = p_{\text{target}}.pmarginal()=logit1(+s)(s;0,s2)ds=ptarget.

    You can compute that integral numerically and find mu with uniroot().

Below I give R code you can drop into your simulation pipeline:

  • a function to compute the marginal prob for a given mu and sd_subject;

  • a solver that returns the mu producing a desired marginal prob;

  • example usage sweeping p = c(0.05,0.10,0.20) with a subject random intercept.

1) Numeric solver for the marginal probability (Binomial/Bernoulli, size = 1)

r
# required: no extra packages
inv_logit <- function(x) 1 / (1 + exp(-x))

# marginal probability given mu and sd_subject:
marginal_prob_given_mu <- function(mu, sd_subject) {
  if (sd_subject == 0) return(inv_logit(mu))  # analytic simple case
  f <- function(u) inv_logit(mu + u) * dnorm(u, mean = 0, sd = sd_subject)
  # integrate over u from -Inf to Inf
  stats::integrate(f, lower = -Inf, upper = Inf, rel.tol = 1e-8)$value
}

# solver: find mu that gives target marginal p (for Bernoulli / Binomial size=1)
find_mu_for_marginal_p <- function(p_target, sd_subject = 0, tol = 1e-8) {
  if (p_target <= 0 || p_target >= 1) stop("p_target must be in (0,1)")
  if (sd_subject == 0) return(qlogis(p_target))  # closed-form
  # function whose root we find:
  froot <- function(mu) marginal_prob_given_mu(mu, sd_subject) - p_target
  # bracket: logistic quantiles are good starting points
  lower <- qlogis(max(1e-10, p_target * 0.1))   # somewhat lower
  upper <- qlogis(min(1-1e-10, p_target + (1 - p_target) * 0.9))
  # widen bracket until sign change (safe guard)
  i <- 0
  while (froot(lower) * froot(upper) > 0 && i < 50) {
    lower <- lower - 2
    upper <- upper + 2
    i <- i + 1
  }
  if (froot(lower) * froot(upper) > 0) stop("Failed to bracket root; try different initial bracket")
  uniroot(froot, lower = lower, upper = upper, tol = tol)$root
}

Notes

  • marginal_prob_given_mu() computes logit1(+u)(u;0,s2)du\int \text{logit}^{-1}(\mu+u) \phi(u;0,\sigma_s^2)\,dulogit1(+u)(u;0,s2)du by numerical integration. This is exact up to integration error.

  • find_mu_for_marginal_p() uses uniroot() to find mu that yields p_target.

2) Example: find intercepts for marginal probs with subject SD = 0.6

r
sd_subj <- 0.6
targets <- c(0.05, 0.10, 0.20)
mu_values <- sapply(targets, find_mu_for_marginal_p, sd_subject = sd_subj)
names(mu_values) <- paste0(targets*100, "%")
mu_values
# these values are the intercepts you should use as the baseline mu
# in the linear predictor when simulating with subject random intercepts ~ N(0, sd_subj^2)

Then use that mu in your GLMM simulation (see next section).

3) Integrate this into your simulation function

Below I show a simulate_glmm_binomial() that:

  • builds a balanced design with subjects,

  • accepts p_target instead of mu if you want to request a marginal probability,

  • automatically solves mu so the population marginal probability is close to p_target.

r
simulate_glmm_binomial <- function(
  m1 = 2, m2 = 2, r = 5,
  n_subj = 50,
  p_target = NULL,        # if set, we solve for mu to match marginal prob
  mu = 0,                 # if p_target is NULL, mu is used directly
  a1 = 0, a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
  sd_subject = 0.6,
  size = 1,
  seed = NULL
) {
  if (!is.null(seed)) set.seed(seed)

  # total observations per subject
  per_subj <- m1 * m2 * r

  SUBJECT <- factor(rep(1:n_subj, each = per_subj))
  X1 <- factor(rep(rep(1:m1, each = m2 * r), times = n_subj))
  X2 <- factor(rep(rep(rep(1:m2, each = r), times = m1), times = n_subj))

  x1 <- as.numeric(X1)
  x2 <- as.numeric(X2)

  # find mu if needed
  if (!is.null(p_target)) {
    mu <- find_mu_for_marginal_p(p_target, sd_subject)
  }

  # subject random intercepts
  s_k <- rnorm(n_subj, 0, sd_subject)
  s <- s_k[SUBJECT]

  eta <- mu + a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*(x1*x2) + s
  p <- plogis(eta)  # conditional probabilities
  Y <- rbinom(length(eta), size = size, prob = p)

  data.frame(SUBJECT, X1, X2, eta, p, Y)
}

Usage example:

r
df05 <- simulate_glmm_binomial(m1=2,m2=2,r=5,n_subj=100,p_target=0.05, sd_subject=0.6, seed=1)
df10 <- simulate_glmm_binomial(m1=2,m2=2,r=5,n_subj=100,p_target=0.10, sd_subject=0.6, seed=2)
df20 <- simulate_glmm_binomial(m1=2,m2=2,r=5,n_subj=100,p_target=0.20, sd_subject=0.6, seed=3)

# check empirical marginal probabilities:
mean(df05$Y)  # ~0.05
mean(df10$Y)  # ~0.10
mean(df20$Y)  # ~0.20

4) More advanced points & caveats

  • Binomial with size > 1 (counts)
    The solver above targets the marginal per-trial probability for Bernoulli (size = 1). For aggregated binomial outcomes (e.g., successes out of size trials), the same p applies per trial; marginal mean of successes will be size * p_marginal. If you want to target marginal proportion of successes, use the same approach.

  • Speed
    The numerical integration in marginal_prob_given_mu() is fast for moderate accuracy. If you need to do this thousands of times (e.g., inner loop of massive simulation), precompute mu for each p_target and sd_subject combination once and reuse.

  • Alternative approximations
    There are analytic approximations for the logistic-normal integral (e.g., using GaussHermite or Laplace approximations) but numerical integration with integrate() is robust and simple.

  • Other families

    • Poisson: if you want a marginal mean _target with random intercepts, you must similarly solve for mu such that
      ()=exp(+u)(u;0,s2)du=target\bar{\lambda}(\mu) = \int \exp(\mu + u)\, \phi(u;0,\sigma_s^2)\,du = \lambda_{\text{target}}()=exp(+u)(u;0,s2)du=target.
      But exp(+u)(u)du=exp(+12s2)\int \exp(\mu + u)\phi(u)\,du = \exp(\mu + \tfrac12\sigma_s^2)exp(+u)(u)du=exp(+21s2). So you can solve analytically:

      =log(target)12s2.\mu = \log(\lambda_{\text{target}}) - \tfrac12\sigma_s^2.=log(target)21s2.

      (So Poisson is simpler: the marginal mean under normal random intercept with variance s2\sigma_s^2s2 is exp(+12s2)\exp(\mu + \tfrac12\sigma_s^2)exp(+21s2).)

    • Exponential / Gamma: similar: marginal mean when adding normal random effect on log-scale has closed form: marginal mean = exp(mu + 0.5 * var_of_random_effect); use this to pick mu.

    • Binomial (logit): no closed form must integrate numerically as shown.

  • When you want conditional probabilities instead of marginal
    If you prefer to keep a conditional probability (i.e., probability for s=0 equal to p_target), just set mu_conditional = qlogis(p_target) and do not solve; but then marginal probability will differ.

5) Quick recipe you can use in experiments

  1. Decide whether you want to target marginal population-level probabilities (what you observe across subjects) or conditional probabilities (probability for a subject with s=0).

  2. If no random effect, set mu = qlogis(p_target).

  3. If random effect and you want marginal p_target, use find_mu_for_marginal_p(p_target, sd_subject) once and plug that mu into your simulation.

  4. Sweep over p_target values (e.g., 0.05, 0.10, 0.20) and/or sd_subject values to evaluate problematic cases.

  • provide code that precomputes mu for a grid of (p_target, sd_subject) values and caches them for fast simulation;

  • produce a full example simulation comparing power/type-I for p = 5%, 10%, 20%; or

  • extend the same approach to multilevel binomial (clustered binomial) or to target marginal means in Poisson and Exponential (with the analytic formulas shown). Which would you like?

You said:
i guess that if a1 > 0 or/and a2 > 0 then these probabilities are not preserved, right?
ChatGPT said:

Great question and yes, you are absolutely right.

Once you introduce fixed effects (a1, a2, a12), the marginal probability for each cell changes, and the single baseline probability you targeted (e.g. 5%, 10%, 20%) is only preserved for the reference cell (typically X1 = 1, X2 = 1), not for the others.

Let me explain clearly.

What happens when a1 > 0 or a2 > 0?

With a logistic GLMM:

ijk=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12(x1ix2j)+sk\eta_{ijk} = \mu + a_1 x1_i + a_2 x2_j + a_{12} (x1_i x2_j) + s_kijk=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12(x1ix2j)+sk pijk=logit1(ijk)p_{ijk} = \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\eta_{ijk})pijk=logit1(ijk)

When:

  • a1 = a2 = a12 = 0, then all cells have the same probability the preserved target probability makes sense.

  • a1 > 0, a2 > 0, or a12 0
    the probabilities differ across cells, and only the baseline cell retains the probability you solved for.

Why the probabilities change across cells

Suppose you want the baseline marginal probability to be 10%.

You compute:

=find_mu(p=0.10,sd_subject)\mu = \text{find\_mu}(p=0.10, sd\_subject)=find_mu(p=0.10,sd_subject)

Now consider two cells:

Baseline cell:

  • x1 = 1, x2 = 1

  • linear predictor = mu + s_k

  • marginal probability 10%

Other cell (e.g. x1 = 2)

  • x1 = 2, so the linear predictor becomes:

    +a1(2)+sk=+a1+sk\mu + a_1(2) + s_k = \mu + a_1 + s_k+a1(2)+sk=+a1+sk

  • if a1 > 0, the probability increases in that cell.

Thus:

The target probability is not preserved across the design once effects are added.

This is exactly how a GLM is supposed to behave.

What is preserved?

What is preserved:

  • The marginal probability for the baseline cell (condition X1=1, X2=1).

  • The relative effect sizes (odds ratios determined by exp(a1), exp(a2)).

  • The random-effect variance.

What is not preserved:

  • A fixed marginal probability across all design cells.

  • A simple mapping between and the overall average P(Y=1).

Example to make this explicit

Assume:

  • baseline prob = 10%

  • a1 = log(3) 1.098 X1=2 triples odds

  • a2 = log(2) 0.693 X2=2 doubles odds

Then:

p110.10p_{11} \approx 0.10p110.10 p21logit1(\logit(0.10)+a1)p_{21} \approx \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\logit(0.10) + a_1)p21logit1(\logit(0.10)+a1) p12logit1(\logit(0.10)+a2)p_{12} \approx \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\logit(0.10) + a_2)p12logit1(\logit(0.10)+a2) p22logit1(\logit(0.10)+a1+a2)p_{22} \approx \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\logit(0.10) + a_1 + a_2)p22logit1(\logit(0.10)+a1+a2)

You will get something like:

CellX1X2Probability
11 (baseline)110.10
2121~0.25
1212~0.18
2222~0.39

These values also change slightly depending on the random-effect variance, because the marginal distribution is the logisticnormal mixture.

So what can you control?

You can control:

1. The baseline probability (via mu solver)

2. The effect sizes (a1, a2, a12)

3. The random-effect variance (sd_subject)

But you cannot force all cells to have the same marginal probability while still having effects > 0.
That would contradict the meaning of an effect.

If you want specific probabilities in each cell

Then we must invert the logistic model for each cell separately:

For each cell (i,j), if you want:

pijtargetp_{ij}^{target}pijtarget

Then you must solve for:

+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j\mu + a_1 x1_i + a_2 x2_j + a_{12} x1_i x2_j+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j

individually.

But then:

  • either varies by cell breaking the GLM structure

  • or a1, a2, a12 must be 0 no effect

so it is impossible to have both non-zero effects and identical probabilities across cells.

Summary

Yes, once a1 or a2 are non-zero, the probabilities are no longer preserved.
Only the baseline cell keeps the targeted probability.
Other cells get probabilities determined by the logistic transformation of the linear predictor.
This is the expected and correct behavior of a GLM.

  • random-effect SD values (0.2, 0.5, 1.0)

You said:
i was rather meaning to control the average probability.
ChatGPT said:

Yes you can target the average (marginal) probability across your whole simulated dataset, even when a1, a2 and random subject effects are non-zero. The idea is simple:

choose mu so that the average marginal probability over every observation (averaging over subject random intercepts) equals your desired target.

For Binomial/Bernoulli with a logistic link this requires numerical integration (no closed form). For Poisson/Exponential (log link) you can solve analytically. Below I give a ready-to-run R implementation that:

  • builds your balanced design (m1 m2 r per subject),

  • for a given mu, a1, a2, a12, and sd_subject computes the marginal probability per observation as
    pij()=logit1(ij+u)(u;0,s2)dup_{ij}(\mu) = \int \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\eta_{ij}+u)\,\phi(u;0,\sigma_s^2)\,dupij()=logit1(ij+u)(u;0,s2)du,

  • averages those probabilities across the whole design to get the dataset average,

  • uses uniroot() to find the mu that produces the desired average probability p_target,

  • returns that mu and lets you simulate with it.

R code solver + example

r
# helper
inv_logit <- function(x) 1 / (1 + exp(-x))

# marginal probability at one observation (integrate over subject random intercept)
marginal_p_obs <- function(eta_ij, sd_subject, rel.tol = 1e-8) {
  if (sd_subject == 0) return(inv_logit(eta_ij))
  f <- function(u) inv_logit(eta_ij + u) * dnorm(u, mean = 0, sd = sd_subject)
  stats::integrate(f, lower = -Inf, upper = Inf, rel.tol = rel.tol)$value
}

# average marginal probability over a design (vectorized)
avg_marginal_prob_for_mu <- function(mu, m1, m2, r,
                                     a1 = 0, a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
                                     sd_subject = 0, coding = "numeric") {
  # create balanced design (one subject template)
  # numeric coding for levels (1..m)
  x1_levels <- 1:m1
  x2_levels <- 1:m2
  # numeric coding choices: numeric levels 1..m or centered (-1,+1) for m=2
  if (coding == "centered" && m1 == 2) enc1 <- c(-1, 1) else enc1 <- x1_levels
  if (coding == "centered" && m2 == 2) enc2 <- c(-1, 1) else enc2 <- x2_levels

  # one-subject template (m1*m2*r rows)
  template <- expand.grid(x1 = enc1, x2 = enc2, rep = 1:r, KEEP.OUT.ATTRS = FALSE)
  # linear predictor per observation (without subject random intercept)
  eta0 <- mu + a1 * template$x1 + a2 * template$x2 + a12 * (template$x1 * template$x2)
  # compute marginal probability for each observation
  p_vec <- vapply(eta0, marginal_p_obs, numeric(1), sd_subject = sd_subject)
  mean(p_vec)   # average marginal probability across observations
}

# main solver: find mu such that average marginal prob == p_target
find_mu_for_avg_p <- function(p_target, m1, m2, r,
                              a1 = 0, a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
                              sd_subject = 0, coding = "numeric",
                              lower = -10, upper = 10, tol = 1e-8) {
  if (p_target <= 0 || p_target >= 1) stop("p_target must be in (0,1)")
  froot <- function(mu) {
    avg_marginal_prob_for_mu(mu, m1, m2, r,
                             a1 = a1, a2 = a2, a12 = a12,
                             sd_subject = sd_subject, coding = coding) - p_target
  }
  # Expand bracket if necessary
  i <- 0
  while (froot(lower) * froot(upper) > 0 && i < 40) {
    lower <- lower - 5
    upper <- upper + 5
    i <- i + 1
  }
  if (froot(lower) * froot(upper) > 0) stop("Failed to bracket root; try different bounds")
  uniroot(froot, lower = lower, upper = upper, tol = tol)$root
}

Example: use it and check by simulating

r
set.seed(123)

# Design and model choices
m1 <- 2; m2 <- 2; r <- 5
a1 <- log(2)   # effect on log-odds (doubling odds)
a2 <- 0
a12 <- 0
sd_subject <- 0.6

targets <- c(0.05, 0.10, 0.20)
mu_found <- sapply(targets, find_mu_for_avg_p,
                   m1 = m1, m2 = m2, r = r,
                   a1 = a1, a2 = a2, a12 = a12,
                   sd_subject = sd_subject)

mu_found
# Now simulate using the found mu and verify empirical avg p
simulate_and_check <- function(mu, reps = 2000) {
  # simulate many datasets and compute empirical average probability
  per_subj <- m1 * m2 * r
  N <- per_subj  # template per subject; we'll simulate many subjects to approximate avg
  # simulate one large dataset (many subjects) for checking
  n_subj_check <- 500
  SUBJECT <- factor(rep(1:n_subj_check, each = per_subj))
  X1 <- factor(rep(rep(1:m1, each = m2 * r), times = n_subj_check))
  X2 <- factor(rep(rep(rep(1:m2, each = r), times = m1), times = n_subj_check))
  x1 <- as.numeric(X1); x2 <- as.numeric(X2)
  s_k <- rnorm(n_subj_check, 0, sd_subject); s <- s_k[SUBJECT]
  eta <- mu + a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*(x1*x2) + s
  p_cond <- plogis(eta)
  Y <- rbinom(length(eta), size = 1, prob = p_cond)
  c(empirical_mean = mean(Y), theoretical_avg = mean(vapply(mu + a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*(x1*x2), marginal_p_obs, numeric(1), sd_subject = sd_subject)))
}

sapply(mu_found, simulate_and_check)

You should see the empirical average probability close to each targets value (differences due to Monte Carlo noise). The theoretical_avg column shows the average marginal probability computed from the integrals (should match the target precisely).

Notes & important remarks

  • Why this is necessary: when a1, a2 are nonzero the per-cell probabilities change; targeting the average over the whole design requires solving for mu that balances those cell-wise changes.

  • Speed: the integrals are inexpensive for moderate designs. If you need to solve repeatedly for many scenarios, you can cache results or use GaussHermite quadrature / approximation for speed.

  • Poisson & Exponential (analytic): if you want to target average marginal mean for Poisson/Exponential with a normal random intercept s ~ N(0,), you can use the identity

    E[exp(+effects+s)]=exp(+effects+122).E[\exp(\mu + \text{effects} + s)] = \exp(\mu + \text{effects} + \tfrac12\sigma^2).E[exp(+effects+s)]=exp(+effects+212).

    So average marginal mean over the design is simply the mean across observations of exp(+effects+0.52)\exp(\mu + effects + 0.5\sigma^2)exp(+effects+0.52), and you can solve for mu analytically (or numerically) much faster.

  • What you control: this procedure sets the dataset-wide average (marginal) probability. Individual cells will still differ according to a1,a2,a12 (which is typically what you want).
