You said:
Adapt it for Binomial with size > 1. I wonder whether it is still possible to achieve the desired probability average in this case (if size is not very large), while also controlling a1 or a2
ChatGPT said:

Yes it is absolutely possible to achieve a desired average probability (or average mean count) in a Binomial(size > 1) GLMM while also having non-zero effects a1, a2 and a random subject effect.

The key is understanding what you want to control:

What quantity do you want to match?

For Binomial(size = m) you have two options:

A. Control the average probability per trial

p=E[Ym]=1mE(Y)\bar p = \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{Y}{m}\right] = \frac{1}{m}\,\mathbb{E}(Y)p=E[mY]=m1E(Y)

This is exactly the same problem as Bernoulli, because:

Ym=average of m Bernoulli trials\frac{Y}{m} = \text{average of } m \text{ Bernoulli trials}mY=average of m Bernoulli trials

Thus, all the mathematics remains unchanged only the final simulation of Y uses rbinom() with size = m rather than rbinom(size=1).

B. Or control the average expected count

E(Y)=mp\mathbb{E}(Y) = m \cdot \bar pE(Y)=mp

Both are achievable.

Most people want A (average per-trial probability), because it scales independently of size.

I will write the solver for A, which matches your question.

IMPORTANT: Do a1, a2 break the ability to target the average?

No.

Even when a1 or a2 create different probabilities across cells, you can always find a value of mu such that:

1Ni=1NE[pi()]=ptarget\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N E[p_i(\mu)] = p_{\text{target}}N1i=1NE[pi()]=ptarget

because the logistic-normal mixture has:

  • mean 0 as

  • mean 1 as +

so the function is continuous and spans (0,1).
Thus, a unique always exists.

The solver is identical to the Bernoulli case

Binomial(k, size=m) m independent Bernoulli trials p is the same.

So the solver code from the Bernoulli case remains correct, only the final simulation changes.

Updated Simulation Code for Binomial(size > 1)

Below I give you a complete block that:

  • solves so that the average marginal success probability equals p_target

  • includes non-zero a1, a2, a12

  • includes random subject intercept

  • works for any size 1

Part 1 Integrate over random effect

r
inv_logit <- function(x) 1 / (1 + exp(-x))

marginal_p_obs <- function(eta_ij, sd_subject, rel.tol = 1e-8) {
  if (sd_subject == 0) return(inv_logit(eta_ij))
  f <- function(u) inv_logit(eta_ij + u) * dnorm(u, 0, sd_subject)
  integrate(f, -Inf, Inf, rel.tol = rel.tol)$value
}

Part 2 Compute design-average marginal probability for a given 

r
avg_marginal_prob_for_mu <- function(mu, m1, m2, r,
                                     a1, a2, a12,
                                     sd_subject, coding = "numeric") {

  x1_levels <- 1:m1
  x2_levels <- 1:m2
  enc1 <- if (coding=="centered" && m1==2) c(-1,1) else x1_levels
  enc2 <- if (coding=="centered" && m2==2) c(-1,1) else x2_levels

  template <- expand.grid(x1 = enc1, x2 = enc2, rep = 1:r, KEEP.OUT.ATTRS = FALSE)

  eta0 <- mu + a1*template$x1 + a2*template$x2 + a12*(template$x1*template$x2)

  p_vec <- vapply(eta0, marginal_p_obs, numeric(1), sd_subject = sd_subject)

  mean(p_vec)
}

Part 3 Solve for so the dataset-average probability = target

r
find_mu_for_avg_p <- function(p_target, m1, m2, r,
                              a1, a2, a12,
                              sd_subject,
                              coding = "numeric",
                              lower = -15, upper = 15) {

  froot <- function(mu) {
    avg_marginal_prob_for_mu(mu, m1, m2, r,
                             a1, a2, a12,
                             sd_subject, coding) - p_target
  }

  # expand bracket if necessary
  i <- 0
  while (froot(lower) * froot(upper) > 0 && i < 40) {
    lower <- lower - 5
    upper <- upper + 5
    i <- i + 1
  }

  if (froot(lower) * froot(upper) > 0)
    stop("Failed to bracket root.")

  uniroot(froot, lower = lower, upper = upper)$root
}

Final Step Simulate Binomial(size > 1)

r
simulate_binomial_glmm <- function(m1, m2, r, n_subj,
                                   a1, a2, a12,
                                   sd_subject,
                                   size,
                                   p_target) {

  # solve for mu that achieves average marginal probability
  mu <- find_mu_for_avg_p(p_target,
                          m1, m2, r,
                          a1, a2, a12,
                          sd_subject)

  # build design
  per_subj <- m1 * m2 * r
  SUBJECT <- factor(rep(1:n_subj, each = per_subj))
  X1 <- factor(rep(rep(1:m1, each = m2*r), times = n_subj))
  X2 <- factor(rep(rep(rep(1:m2, each = r), times = m1), times = n_subj))
  x1 <- as.numeric(X1)
  x2 <- as.numeric(X2)

  # random intercepts
  s_k <- rnorm(n_subj, 0, sd_subject)
  s <- s_k[SUBJECT]

  # conditional probabilities
  eta <- mu + a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*(x1*x2) + s
  p_cond <- plogis(eta)

  # simulate Binomial responses
  Y <- rbinom(length(eta), size = size, prob = p_cond)

  data.frame(SUBJECT, X1, X2, eta, p = p_cond, Y)
}

r

df <- simulate_binomial_glmm(
  m1 = 2, m2 = 2, r = 5,
  n_subj = 300,
  a1 = log(2), a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
  sd_subject = 0.7,
  size = 8,
  p_target = 0.10
)

mean(df$Y / 8)

This will be very close to 0.10, even with:

  • size = 8 (or any size)

  • non-zero a1

  • random subject intercept

Target probability is preserved on average.

Is it possible to control the average probability in Binomial(size > 1)?

Yes, completely.

Do a1 and a2 break this?

No.
They change cell-wise probabilities, but adjusts so that the whole dataset average matches the target.

1Nall obsE(pij)=ptarget\frac{1}{N}\sum_{\text{all obs}} \mathbb{E}(p_{ij}) = p_{\text{target}}N1all obsE(pij)=ptarget

You said:
wait, if the design is centered, isn't the solution easier?
ChatGPT said:

Short answer: Yes centering the design helps, but how much it simplifies depends on the family.
For linear (Gaussian) and for log-link families where you can move the mean outside the nonlinearity (Poisson / Exponential / Gamma with log link) you can get closed-form adjustments using the fact that the design averages of the centered effects are zero or at least reduce the algebra. For the logistic (Binomial / Bernoulli) case you still need a numerical solve because of the nonlinearity of the inverse-logit, but centering reduces the problem and gives a very good initial guess.

Below I give the math + practical formulas and short R snippets you can drop into your pipeline.

1) Notation and "centered" design

Use numeric encodings x1i,x2jx_{1i},x_{2j}x1i,x2j chosen so that their cell-wise average (over the balanced design) is 0 e.g. sum-to-zero contrasts for categorical factors (for two-level factors use 1,+1-1,+11,+1), or grand-mean centering for continuous covariates. Also assume the interaction encoding is defined so its average across cells is 0.

Linear predictor with subject random intercept sN(0,s2)s\sim N(0,\sigma_s^2)sN(0,s2):

ijk=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j+sk.\eta_{ijk} = \mu + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12} x_{1i}x_{2j} + s_k.ijk=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j+sk.

Because the design is balanced and encodings are sum-to-zero:

1Nall obs(a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2)=0.\frac{1}{N}\sum_{\text{all obs}} (a_1 x_{1} + a_2 x_{2} + a_{12} x_1 x_2) = 0.N1all obs(a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2)=0.

So the average linear predictor across cells (excluding s) equals \mu.

2) Gaussian (identity link) trivial

Y=+,N(0,2).Y = \eta + \epsilon,\quad \epsilon\sim N(0,\sigma_\epsilon^2).Y=+,N(0,2).

Average marginal mean across the design (and over subjects) is simply

=1NobsE[Y]=1Nobs(+effects)=.\bar\mu = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{obs} E[Y] = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{obs} (\mu + \text{effects}) = \mu.=N1obsE[Y]=N1obs(+effects)=.

So if the design is centered, set =ptarget\mu = p_{\text{target}}=ptarget (or =\mu == target mean). No solver needed.

3) Poisson / Exponential / Gamma with log link closed-form solution

For log-link families the conditional mean is

mij,kE[Yx,s]=exp(ijk)=exp(+effects+sk).m_{ij,k} \equiv E[Y \mid x,s] = \exp(\eta_{ijk}) = \exp(\mu + \text{effects} + s_k).mij,kE[Yx,s]=exp(ijk)=exp(+effects+sk).

Averaging over the normal random intercept sks_ksk (with variance s2\sigma_s^2s2) gives

Es[mij,k]=exp(+effects)E[exp(sk)]=exp(+effects)exp(12s2).E_{s}[m_{ij,k}] = \exp(\mu + \text{effects}) \cdot E[\exp(s_k)] = \exp(\mu + \text{effects}) \cdot \exp\!\Big(\tfrac12\sigma_s^2\Big).Es[mij,k]=exp(+effects)E[exp(sk)]=exp(+effects)exp(21s2).

Now average across the balanced design (cells):

m()=1NobsEs[mij,k]=exp(+12s2)1Nobsexp(effects).\bar m(\mu) = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{obs} E_s[m_{ij,k}] = \exp\!\Big(\mu + \tfrac12\sigma_s^2\Big) \cdot \frac{1}{N}\sum_{obs}\exp(\text{effects}).m()=N1obsEs[mij,k]=exp(+21s2)N1obsexp(effects).

Because the effects average to zero on the linear scale does not imply** 1Nexp(effects)=1\frac1N \sum \exp(\text{effects}) = 1N1exp(effects)=1**. But we can compute the design average E=1Nobsexp(effects)\bar E = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{obs}\exp(\text{effects})E=N1obsexp(effects) easily (it depends only on a1,a2,a12a_1,a_2,a_{12}a1,a2,a12 and the encoding).

Thus the dataset-average mean is

m()=exp(+12s2) E.\bar m(\mu) = \exp\!\Big(\mu + \tfrac12\sigma_s^2\Big)\ \bar E.m()=exp(+21s2) E.

We want m()=mtarget\bar m(\mu) = m_{\text{target}}m()=mtarget (target average count/mean). Solve for \mu analytically:

=log(mtarget)12s2log(E).\mu = \log(m_{\text{target}}) - \tfrac12\sigma_s^2 - \log(\bar E).=log(mtarget)21s2log(E).

  • For Poisson: set mtargetm_{\text{target}}mtarget = target mean (counts).

  • For Exponential / Gamma (mean parametrizations): same algebra applies if you target average mean.

R code snippet to compute E\bar EE and \mu:

r
# compute design-average of exp(effects)
compute_mu_loglink <- function(m1, m2, r, a1, a2, a12, sigma_s, m_target, coding="centered") {
  # build template (one-subject)
  if (coding=="centered" && m1==2) enc1 <- c(-1, 1) else enc1 <- 1:m1
  if (coding=="centered" && m2==2) enc2 <- c(-1, 1) else enc2 <- 1:m2
  tpl <- expand.grid(x1 = enc1, x2 = enc2, rep = 1:r)
  effects <- a1 * tpl$x1 + a2 * tpl$x2 + a12 * (tpl$x1 * tpl$x2)
  Ebar <- mean(exp(effects))
  mu <- log(m_target) - 0.5 * sigma_s^2 - log(Ebar)
  list(mu = mu, Ebar = Ebar)
}

So centering removes the need to consider linear average of effects (it is 0), but you still must account for E\bar EE computable and plug-in; hence an analytic closed-form mu exists.

4) Binomial / Bernoulli (logit link) still numeric, but simpler

For logistic link the conditional probability is pijk=logit1(ijk)p_{ijk} = \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\eta_{ijk})pijk=logit1(ijk). The dataset-average marginal probability equals

p()=1Nobslogit1(+effects+u)(u;0,s2)du.\bar p(\mu) = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{obs} \int \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu + \text{effects} + u)\, \phi(u;0,\sigma_s^2)\,du.p()=N1obslogit1(+effects+u)(u;0,s2)du.

If the design is centered then the average of effects over the design is zero, implying that the average linear predictor (without s) is \mu. However, because logit1\operatorname{logit}^{-1}logit1 is nonlinear, you cannot pull \mu out of the integral to get a closed form. So you must still solve numerically for \mu such that p()=ptarget\bar p(\mu) = p_{\text{target}}p()=ptarget.

Why centered helps:

  • you only need to solve for a single scalar \mu (not a more complex intercept vector), and a good initial guess is the unconditional logit: 0=logit(ptarget)\mu_0 = \operatorname{logit}(p_{\text{target}})0=logit(ptarget).

  • the search is easier and faster because the effects sum to zero and the function p()\bar p(\mu)p() is monotone in \mu.

R snippet (fast) centered coding + uniroot:

r
# marginal p at single eta (integrate over subject u)
marginal_p_obs <- function(eta0, sd_subject) {
  if (sd_subject == 0) return(1/(1 + exp(-eta0)))
  f <- function(u) 1/(1 + exp(-(eta0 + u))) * dnorm(u, 0, sd_subject)
  integrate(f, -Inf, Inf)$value
}

# average over design (effects centered so mean(effects)=0)
avg_p_given_mu <- function(mu, m1, m2, r, a1, a2, a12, sd_subject, coding="centered") {
  if (coding=="centered" && m1==2) enc1 <- c(-1,1) else enc1 <- 1:m1
  if (coding=="centered" && m2==2) enc2 <- c(-1,1) else enc2 <- 1:m2
  tpl <- expand.grid(x1=enc1, x2=enc2, rep=1:r)
  etas <- mu + a1*tpl$x1 + a2*tpl$x2 + a12*(tpl$x1*tpl$x2)
  mean(vapply(etas, marginal_p_obs, numeric(1), sd_subject=sd_subject))
}
# solve
mu_hat <- uniroot(function(mu) avg_p_given_mu(mu, m1,m2,r,a1,a2,a12,sd_subject) - p_target,
                  lower=-15, upper=15)$root

5) Practical recommendations / summary

  • Yes centering helps: it makes the linear predictor average across the design equal to \mu, so you only need to solve for that single scalar intercept. It removes the need to shift/adjust for the arithmetic mean of effects on the linear scale.

  • Closed-form for log-link families (Poisson/Exponential/Gamma): you can compute \mu analytically using the formula above, provided you compute E=meanx[exp(effects)]\bar E = \text{mean}_x[\exp(\text{effects})]E=meanx[exp(effects)].

  • Numerical for logit (Binomial): centering simplifies the root-finding (good initial guess, smaller search), but you still must use numerical integration and root-finding.

  • Implementation: compute E\bar EE (easy), plug into the formula for log-link, or run the numeric solver for logistic. Precompute \mu for each scenario (grid of a1/a2/sigma_s) and cache them for speed.

If you want, I can:

  • show a short numeric example comparing centered vs uncentered solves (Binomial and Poisson),

  • add code to your existing simulation function to auto-detect centered encodings and pick the analytic vs numeric branch, or

  • produce a utility that precomputes and caches \mu over a grid of (p_target, a1, a2, sigma_s) for very large simulation studies. Which would you like?

You said:
but why is it not enough to chose mu = dlogis(p_target) ?
ChatGPT said:

Great question this is exactly the key point where intuition from the linear/identity-link case breaks down.

Why = logit(p_target) is not enough in the logistic mixed model

Suppose you try:

=logit(ptarget)\mu = \operatorname{logit}(p_{\text{target}})=logit(ptarget)

This would work only if:

p()=1NobsE[Yijk]=1Nobslogit1(ijk)=ptarget\bar p(\mu) = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{\text{obs}} E[Y_{ijk}] = \frac{1}{N}\sum_{\text{obs}} \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\eta_{ijk}) = p_{\text{target}}p()=N1obsE[Yijk]=N1obslogit1(ijk)=ptarget

for all effects and for all subject random effects.

But this is not true in logistic models with:

  1. nonzero fixed effects (a, a, a 0),

  2. and/or subject random intercept variance ( > 0).

Why?

Reason 1 The logistic function is nonlinear (convexconcave)

The logit link is nonlinear, so:

logit1(+effects)average logistic().\operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu + \text{effects}) \neq \text{average logistic}\left(\mu\right).logit1(+effects)=average logistic().

Even if the design is perfectly centered (so average effects = 0):

avgxlogit1(+effects)logit1()\operatorname{avg}_x\; \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu + \text{effects}) \neq \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu)avgxlogit1(+effects)=logit1()

Because:

E[logit1(X)]logit1(E[X])E[\operatorname{logit}^{-1}(X)] \neq \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(E[X])E[logit1(X)]=logit1(E[X])

This is Jensens inequality.

So introducing any effect (say a > 0) changes the average probability away from logit^{-1}(). The only way to correct for this is solving for the that restores the desired average.

Reason 2 Random intercepts distort the mean

Let sN(0,s2)s \sim N(0,\sigma_s^2)sN(0,s2).

Even if effects = 0:

Es[logit1(+s)]logit1()E_s[\operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu + s)] \neq \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu)Es[logit1(+s)]=logit1()

Actually:

  • Subject heterogeneity pushes marginal probabilities toward 0.5.

  • Larger = stronger shrinkage toward 0.5.

So if you want average probability = p_target = 0.10:

=\logit(0.10)\mu = \logit(0.10)=\logit(0.10)

will give something larger than 0.10 because variation in sss inflates the average.

To fix this, you must numerically solve:

p()=ptarget.\bar p(\mu) = p_{\text{target}}.p()=ptarget.

Reason 3 Fixed effects also distort the mean even when centered

Again because logit^{-1} is nonlinear:

If a 0 or a 0:

Even if x and x are centered so that E[x]=0,

E[logit1(+a1x1)]logit1()E[\operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu + a_1 x_1)] \neq \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu)E[logit1(+a1x1)]=logit1()

You cannot cancel effects by centering because the transformation is nonlinear.

Summary

CaseDoes = logit(p_target) work?Why not?
No fixed effects, no random effectsYesOnly then the inverse-logit preserves the mean
Fixed effects presentNonlinearity makes avg(logit^{-1}) logit^{-1}(avg)
Random intercept presentHeterogeneity pulls probabilities toward 0.5
Fixed + random effectsBoth distort the marginal mean

So the correct must satisfy:

1Nlogit1(+effects+s)f(s)ds=ptarget,\frac{1}{N}\sum \int \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\mu + \text{effects} + s)\, f(s)\,ds = p_{\text{target}},N1logit1(+effects+s)f(s)ds=ptarget,

which requires a numerical solver (but only 1D).

Very short practical rule

= logit(p_target) only works for simple Bernoulli GLM with no random effects and no fixed effects.
In all mixed or multi-factor designs you need the root-finding step.

r
mu_for_target_binomial()

that:

  • accepts p_target, sigma_s, a1, a2, a12, levels, etc.,

  • automatically centers the design,

  • uses GaussHermite quadrature instead of slow integrate(),

  • solves for quickly (< 5 ms).

ChatGPT said:

Yes, its clear and its a reasonable and flexible way to create centered codings for factors with any number of levels (balanced design).
Below I give you one unified R framework that covers:

  • Binomial with size > 1 and target probability

  • Poisson with target

  • Exponential with target rate (or mean)

  • Log-normal with target log-mean

All using:

  1. Your centered coding

  2. Your fixed-effects:
    =+a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2+s\eta = \mu + a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + a_{12} x_1 x_2 + s=+a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2+s

    (closed-form where possible, numerical otherwise)

Everything is written modularly and ready to plug into simulations.

1. Centered coding function (your version, included)

This produces values whose range = 1 and mean = 0:

r
coding <- function(nlevels) { 
  levels <- sort(c(0, 1, runif(nlevels - 2)))
  return(levels - mean(levels))
}

This is valid and produces non-collinear encodings.

2. Utility: Generate the design matrix (balanced)

r
make_design <- function(m1, m2, reps = 1) {
  x1 <- coding(m1)
  x2 <- coding(m2)
  expand.grid(x1 = x1, x2 = x2, rep = 1:reps)
}

3. Compute linear predictor effects

Given the design and fixed effects:

r
compute_effects <- function(design, a1, a2, a12) {
  with(design, a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*(x1*x2))
}

4. Subject random intercept generator

r
subject_random <- function(nsubjects, sigma_s) {
  rnorm(nsubjects, 0, sigma_s)
}

5. Closed-form for Poisson & Exponential & Log-normal

(These use log-link or multiplicative variance structure)

5A. Poisson with target mean *

We want:

E[Y]=targetE[Y] = \lambda_{\text{target}}E[Y]=target

For Poisson/log-link:

E[Y]=e+12s2Ex[eeffects]E[Y] = e^{\mu + \frac12\sigma_s^2}\, E_x[e^{\text{effects}}]E[Y]=e+21s2Ex[eeffects]

Solve for :

r
mu_poisson <- function(effects, sigma_s, lambda_target) {
  Ebar <- mean(exp(effects))
  mu <- log(lambda_target) - 0.5 * sigma_s^2 - log(Ebar)
  return(mu)
}

5B. Exponential with target rate (or mean)

If Exponential with rate = r_target, then mean = 1/r1/r1/r.
The model uses:

E[Y]=eE[Y] = e^{\eta}E[Y]=e

So identical to the Poisson case (just targeting a different mean):

r
mu_exponential <- function(effects, sigma_s, rate_target) {
  mean_target <- 1 / rate_target
  Ebar <- mean(exp(effects))
  mu <- log(mean_target) - 0.5 * sigma_s^2 - log(Ebar)
  return(mu)
}

5C. Log-normal with target log-mean

If:

Y=exp(+),N(0,e2)Y = \exp(\eta + \epsilon),\quad \epsilon\sim N(0,\sigma_e^2)Y=exp(+),N(0,e2)

Then:

E[Y]=e+12(s2+e2)Ex[eeffects]E[Y] = e^{\mu + \frac12(\sigma_s^2+\sigma_e^2)} \, E_x[e^{\text{effects}}]E[Y]=e+21(s2+e2)Ex[eeffects]

Solve for :

r
mu_lognormal <- function(effects, sigma_s, sigma_e, mean_target) {
  Ebar <- mean(exp(effects))
  mu <- log(mean_target) - 0.5*(sigma_s^2 + sigma_e^2) - log(Ebar)
  return(mu)
}

6. Binomial(size > 1) with target mean probability

This is the only case requiring a numerical solver.

Target:

E[Y]=sizeptargetE[Y] = \text{size}\cdot p_{\text{target}}E[Y]=sizeptarget

Let:

p()=logit1()p(\eta) = \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\eta)p()=logit1()

Marginal probability for each observation (integrating over random subject effects):

r
marginal_p_obs <- function(eta0, sigma_s) {
  if (sigma_s == 0)
    return(1/(1 + exp(-eta0)))
  f <- function(u) 1/(1 + exp(-(eta0 + u))) * dnorm(u, 0, sigma_s)
  integrate(f, -Inf, Inf)$value
}

Average over design:

r
avg_p <- function(mu, effects, sigma_s) {
  etas <- mu + effects
  mean(sapply(etas, marginal_p_obs, sigma_s = sigma_s))
}

Solve for :

r
mu_binomial <- function(effects, sigma_s, p_target, size) {

  f <- function(mu) {
    avg_p(mu, effects, sigma_s) - p_target
  }

  # initial guess = logit(p_target)
  mu0 <- qlogis(p_target)

  uniroot(f, interval = c(mu0-10, mu0+10))$root
}

7. Generating the data (final unified function)

Here is one high-level generator using all the pieces:

r
simulate_response <- function(
  m1, m2, reps, nsubjects,
  a1, a2, a12,
  sigma_s,
  family = c("binomial", "poisson", "exponential", "lognormal"),
  size = NULL,
  p_target = NULL,
  lambda_target = NULL,
  rate_target = NULL,
  meanlog_target = NULL,
  sigma_e = NULL
) {

  family <- match.arg(family)

  design <- make_design(m1, m2, reps)
  effects <- compute_effects(design, a1, a2, a12)
  
  # Compute mu depending on family:
  if (family == "poisson") {
    mu <- mu_poisson(effects, sigma_s, lambda_target)
  }
  else if (family == "exponential") {
    mu <- mu_exponential(effects, sigma_s, rate_target)
  }
  else if (family == "lognormal") {
    mu <- mu_lognormal(effects, sigma_s, sigma_e, meanlog_target)
  }
  else if (family == "binomial") {
    mu <- mu_binomial(effects, sigma_s, p_target, size)
  }

  # Add subjects
  subject_ids <- rep(1:nsubjects, each = nrow(design))
  s <- rnorm(nsubjects, 0, sigma_s)
  eta <- mu + effects + s[subject_ids]

  # Generate response
  if (family == "poisson") {
    Y <- rpois(length(eta), exp(eta))
  }
  else if (family == "exponential") {
    Y <- rexp(length(eta), rate = 1/exp(eta))
  }
  else if (family == "lognormal") {
    Y <- rlnorm(length(eta), eta, sigma_e)
  }
  else if (family == "binomial") {
    p <- plogis(eta)
    Y <- rbinom(length(eta), size = size, prob = p)
  }

  data.frame(design, subject = subject_ids, eta = eta, Y = Y)
}

Summary

DistributionLink solvable analytically?Code
Poissonlog yesmu_poisson()
Exponentiallog yesmu_exponential()
Log-normallog-mean yesmu_lognormal()
Binomial (size>1)logit must solve numericallymu_binomial()

Your centered coding method works perfectly with these formulas.

You said:
For the lognormal, does it make also sense to have a target standard deviation (across all data)?
ChatGPT said:

Yes you can target a desired marginal standard deviation for log-normal data, but it is not as simple as targeting the mean, and there are two different standard deviations you may mean.

Lets disambiguate, then Ill show you what is possible and give you code.

1. Two different SDs exist in a log-normal model

Log-normal arises as

Y=exp(+),N(0,e2)Y = \exp(\eta + \epsilon),\quad \epsilon\sim N(0,\sigma_e^2)Y=exp(+),N(0,e2)

with:

=+fixed effects+s,sN(0,s2)\eta = \mu + \text{fixed effects} + s, \qquad s \sim N(0,\sigma_s^2)=+fixed effects+s,sN(0,s2)

This implies that the distribution of log(Y) is Normal with variance:

Var[logY]=e2+s2+Var(fixed effects).\operatorname{Var}[\log Y] = \sigma_e^2 + \sigma_s^2 + \operatorname{Var}(\text{fixed effects}).Var[logY]=e2+s2+Var(fixed effects).

But the distribution of Y itself has marginal standard deviation:

SD[Y]=E[Y2](E[Y])2\operatorname{SD}[Y] = \sqrt{ \mathbb{E}[Y^2] - (\mathbb{E}[Y])^2 }SD[Y]=E[Y2](E[Y])2

which depends on:

  • fixed effects (a, a, a),

  • their coding,

  • (random intercept variance),

  • (log-scale noise),

  • (which controls the mean).

You can target either of these two:

(A) Target SD of log(Y)

This is trivial:

SDlogY=e2+s2+Var(effects)SD_{\log Y} = \sqrt{ \sigma_e^2 + \sigma_s^2 + \operatorname{Var}(\text{effects}) }SDlogY=e2+s2+Var(effects)

and you can solve for easily.

(B) Target SD of Y (the actual data)

This is possible, but does not affect SD, and influences the SD highly nonlinearly.

You must solve for numerically.

2. Important realization

In log-normal data:

Mean(Y) is controlled by

(because its inside exp())

SD(Y) is controlled almost entirely by and

(and also by the spread of fixed effects)

This means:

  • If you want a target mean, choose analytically (as before).

  • If you want a target SD, you should solve numerically for .

3. Is it reasonable to target SD of Y?

Yes, but only after deciding if the SD is marginal (over subjects) or conditional.

Most simulation frameworks do marginal SD, which means:

Standard deviation across all synthetic data points.

This is what I assume.

4. Formula for marginal SD of log-normal Y

Given:

Y=exp(+),N(0,e2),sN(0,s2)Y = \exp(\eta + \epsilon), \quad \epsilon\sim N(0,\sigma_e^2), \quad s\sim N(0,\sigma_s^2)Y=exp(+),N(0,e2),sN(0,s2)

Let:

=1Nxeeffects(x)\alpha = \frac{1}{N}\sum_x e^{\text{effects}(x)}=N1xeeffects(x)

Then:

E[Y]=ee12(s2+e2)E[Y] = e^{\mu}\, e^{\frac12(\sigma_s^2+\sigma_e^2)}\, \alphaE[Y]=ee21(s2+e2) E[Y2]=e2e2(s2+e2)1Nxe2effects(x)E[Y^2] = e^{2\mu}\, e^{2(\sigma_s^2+\sigma_e^2)}\, \frac{1}{N}\sum_x e^{2\,\text{effects}(x)}E[Y2]=e2e2(s2+e2)N1xe2effects(x)

So:

SD(Y)=E[Y2]E[Y]2.SD(Y) = \sqrt{E[Y^2] - E[Y]^2}.SD(Y)=E[Y2]E[Y]2.

Since only appears nonlinearly, we can solve numerically for given a target SD.

5. R code to solve for given a target SD

r
solve_sigma_e_for_lognorm <- function(
  effects, sigma_s, mu, sd_target
) {
  # Precompute these:
  E1 <- mean(exp(effects))
  E2 <- mean(exp(2*effects))

  f <- function(sigma_e) {
    EY  <- exp(mu + 0.5*(sigma_s^2 + sigma_e^2)) * E1
    EY2 <- exp(2*mu + 2*(sigma_s^2 + sigma_e^2)) * E2
    sd <- sqrt(EY2 - EY^2)
    sd - sd_target
  }

  uniroot(f, c(1e-6, 10))$root
}

6. How you integrate this into your simulation

Step 1 Choose target mean

Use the analytic formula:

r
mu <- mu_lognormal(effects, sigma_s, sigma_e, mean_target)

Step 2 Solve for so SD(Y) matches sd_target

r
sigma_e <- solve_sigma_e_for_lognorm(effects, sigma_s, mu, sd_target)

Step 3 Regenerate (because changed the mean!)

Yes this is important:

appears in the marginal mean:

E[Y]=e+12(s2+e2)E[Y] = e^{\mu + \frac12(\sigma_s^2+\sigma_e^2)}\, \alphaE[Y]=e+21(s2+e2)

If changes, must be recomputed.

So the correct loop is:

r
sigma_e <- initial_guess   # maybe 0.5 or 1

repeat {
  mu <- mu_lognormal(effects, sigma_s, sigma_e, mean_target)
  sigma_e_new <- solve_sigma_e_for_lognorm(effects, sigma_s, mu, sd_target)

  if (abs(sigma_e_new - sigma_e) < 1e-6) break
  sigma_e <- sigma_e_new
}

This converges fast in practice (13 iterations).

7. Practical advice

Yes, its meaningful to control SD(Y)

Especially when you want heavy-tailed vs. light-tailed log-normal scenarios.

But note:

  • Means and SDs are not independent in log-normal.

  • Fixing both is possible only because you choose and solve numerically.

  • Random intercept also inflates the SD.

The variation between factor levels (effects) also increases SD(Y)

So you should check SD after generating a full synthetic sample.

Final answer (short)

Yes, it makes sense to target the marginal standard deviation for log-normal data.
To do this:

  • Use your existing analytic formula to get (for mean target).

  • Solve numerically for such that the marginal SD matches a target.

  • Because depends on , iterate until convergence.

ChatGPT said:

Great Case A is much simpler:

Case A: Target SD of log(Y) rather than SD of Y

This means you want to control:

SDlog(Y)=Var(logY).SD_{\log(Y)} = \sqrt{ \operatorname{Var}(\log Y) }.SDlog(Y)=Var(logY).

With:

Y=exp(+),N(0,e2),Y = \exp(\eta + \epsilon),\quad \epsilon \sim N(0,\sigma_e^2),Y=exp(+),N(0,e2), =+effects+s,sN(0,s2),\eta = \mu + \text{effects} + s,\quad s\sim N(0,\sigma_s^2),=+effects+s,sN(0,s2),

we have:

logY=+effects+s+.\log Y = \mu + \text{effects} + s + \epsilon.logY=+effects+s+.

So:

Var(logY)=Var(effects)+s2+e2\operatorname{Var}(\log Y) = \operatorname{Var}(\text{effects}) + \sigma_s^2 + \sigma_e^2Var(logY)=Var(effects)+s2+e2

Given your coding function, effects are centered, so no cross terms.

Thus:

SDlog(Y)2=e2+s2+Var(effects)SD_{\log(Y)}^2 = \sigma_e^2 + \sigma_s^2 + \operatorname{Var}(\text{effects})SDlog(Y)2=e2+s2+Var(effects)

If you want a target:

sdlogY,sd_{\log Y}^\ast,sdlogY,

then the required is:

e2=(sdlogY)2s2Var(effects)\sigma_e^2 = (sd_{\log Y}^\ast)^2 - \sigma_s^2 - \operatorname{Var}(\text{effects})e2=(sdlogY)2s2Var(effects)

and this is valid as long as the right side is 0.

Important

This is extremely clean and does not require a numerical solver.
You completely bypass the complexities of the marginal mean/variance on the Y scale.

Practical code

Compute effects

r
effects <- compute_effects(design, a1, a2, a12)

Compute variance of effects

r
var_eff <- var(effects)

Get given target log-SD

r
sigma_e_for_log_sd <- function(sdlog_target, var_eff, sigma_s) {
  sig2 <- sdlog_target^2 - sigma_s^2 - var_eff
  if (sig2 < 0) stop("Target log-SD is too small for given random effects and fixed-effects variability.")
  sqrt(sig2)
}

Then compute for target mean(Y)

Because mean(Y) is:

E[Y]=exp(+12(s2+e2))Ex[eeffects]E[Y] = \exp(\mu + \tfrac12(\sigma_s^2 + \sigma_e^2)) E_x[e^{\text{effects}}]E[Y]=exp(+21(s2+e2))Ex[eeffects]

so:

r
mu <- function(effects, sigma_s, sigma_e, mean_target) {
  Ebar <- mean(exp(effects))
  log(mean_target) - 0.5*(sigma_s^2 + sigma_e^2) - log(Ebar)
}

Example usage

r

sigma_e <- sigma_e_for_log_sd(sdlog_target, var_eff, sigma_s)

mu_val <- mu_lognormal(effects, sigma_s, sigma_e, mean_target)

Now your log-normal simulation parameters are:

  • = mu_val

  • _e = sigma_e

  • _s = (given)

Perfectly matching your target:

  • mean(Y) = mean_target

  • SD(log Y) = sdlog_target

Updated simulate_response() function

r
simulate_response <- function(
    design, 
    dist = c("binomial","poisson","exponential","lognormal","cauchy"),
    a1 = 0, a2 = 0, a12 = 0,
    sigma_s = 0,        # random subject SD
    size = NULL,        # for binomial
    p_target = NULL,    # for binomial
    lambda_target = NULL, # for poisson
    rate_target = NULL,   # for exponential
    mean_target = NULL,   # for lognormal
    sdlog_target = NULL,  # for lognormal
    gamma = NULL          # for Cauchy scale parameter
) {

  dist <- match.arg(dist)

  # -----------------------------
  # Compute linear predictor
  # -----------------------------
  effects <- a1 * design$x1 + a2 * design$x2 + a12 * design$x1 * design$x2
  var_eff <- var(effects)

  # Random subject intercepts
  if (sigma_s > 0) {
    subj_eff <- rnorm(length(unique(design$subject)), 0, sigma_s)
    design$s <- subj_eff[design$subject]
  } else {
    design$s <- 0
  }

  # -----------------------------
  # BINOMIAL (size > 1)
  # -----------------------------
  if (dist == "binomial") {
    if (is.null(size) || is.null(p_target))
      stop("Binomial requires size and p_target")

    # mean(logit p) = logit(p_target) because coding is centered
    mu <- qlogis(p_target)

    eta <- mu + effects + design$s
    p <- plogis(eta)

    Y <- rbinom(nrow(design), size = size, prob = p)

    return(data.frame(design, eta, p, Y))
  }

  # -----------------------------
  # POISSON
  # -----------------------------
  if (dist == "poisson") {
    if (is.null(lambda_target))
      stop("Poisson requires lambda_target")

    # E[Y] = exp(mu) because effects centered + random effect centered
    mu <- log(lambda_target)

    eta <- mu + effects + design$s
    lambda <- exp(eta)

    Y <- rpois(nrow(design), lambda)

    return(data.frame(design, eta, lambda, Y))
  }

  # -----------------------------
  # EXPONENTIAL
  # -----------------------------
  if (dist == "exponential") {
    if (is.null(rate_target))
      stop("Exponential requires rate_target")

    # E[Y] = 1/rate_target  use log-link: mean = exp(eta)
    mu <- log(1 / rate_target)

    eta <- mu + effects + design$s
    meanY <- exp(eta)
    rate <- 1 / meanY

    Y <- rexp(nrow(design), rate)

    return(data.frame(design, eta, rate, Y))
  }

  # -----------------------------
  # LOGNORMAL (CASE A ONLY)
  # Target: mean(Y), sd(log Y)
  # -----------------------------
  if (dist == "lognormal") {
    if (is.null(mean_target) || is.null(sdlog_target))
      stop("Lognormal requires mean_target and sdlog_target")

    # Total log-variance = var(effects) + sigma_s^2 + sigma_e^2
    #  solve for sigma_e
    sig2_e <- sdlog_target^2 - var_eff - sigma_s^2
    if (sig2_e < 0)
      stop("Target sdlog is too small for this effect structure + sigma_s")

    sigma_e <- sqrt(sig2_e)

    # Solve  such that mean(Y) = mean_target
    # E[Y] = exp(  + ( _s^2 + _e^2 ) ) * mean(exp(effects))
    Eeff <- mean(exp(effects))
    mu <- log(mean_target) - 0.5*(sigma_s^2 + sigma_e^2) - log(Eeff)

    # Linear predictor
    eta <- mu + effects + design$s

    # Simulate Y
    Y <- rlnorm(nrow(design), meanlog = eta, sdlog = sigma_e)

    return(data.frame(design, eta, sigma_e, Y))
  }

  # -----------------------------
  # CAUCHY
  # Y ~ Cauchy(location = , scale = )
  # -----------------------------
  if (dist == "cauchy") {
    if (is.null(gamma))
      stop("Cauchy requires gamma (scale parameter)")

    mu <- 0  # centered location because mean is undefined anyway
    eta <- mu + effects + design$s

    Y <- eta + rcauchy(nrow(design), location = 0, scale = gamma)

    return(data.frame(design, eta, Y))
  }
}

coding <- function(nlevels) { 
  levels <- sort(c(0,1, runif(nlevels-2)))
  levels - mean(levels)
}

ensures:

  • mean(x1x2) = 0

  • fixed effects and random effects do not change the mean location

This greatly simplifies formulas for:

You said:
Wait. For the exponential distribution. Does it make sense to say that we target a average rate? Wouldn't it make more sense to target an overall mean?
ChatGPT said:

Short answer: Yes you should target the overall mean, not the average rate.
Targeting an average rate is not well-defined once you include effects and random intercepts.

Let me explain clearly.

Exponential distribution parameterization

There are two common parameterizations:

  1. Rate form

YExponential()E[Y]=1Y \sim \text{Exponential}(\lambda) \qquad\Rightarrow\qquad E[Y] = \frac{1}{\lambda}YExponential()E[Y]=1

  1. Mean form

YExponential(mean=Y)=1/YY \sim \text{Exponential}(\text{mean} = \mu_Y) \qquad\Rightarrow\qquad \lambda = 1/\mu_YYExponential(mean=Y)=1/Y

A GLM with log link uses:

Y=exp()\mu_Y = \exp(\eta)Y=exp()

NOT the rate.

What happens when you have fixed-effects and random effects?

Your model:

=+(effects)+sk\eta = \mu + (\text{effects}) + s_k=+(effects)+sk

and then:

YExponential(mean=exp())Y \sim \text{Exponential}(\text{mean} = \exp(\eta))YExponential(mean=exp())

So the cell mean varies because exp() varies.

Thus:

  • The rate varies by cell:

    ijk=1exp(ijk)\lambda_{ijk} = \frac{1}{\exp(\eta_{ijk})}ijk=exp(ijk)1

  • The average rate depends on the design, the effect sizes, and the random effects distribution.

There is no coherent single average rate once varies.

Trying to target an average rate means you attempt to solve:

E[1exp()]E\left[ \frac{1}{\exp(\eta)} \right]E[exp()1]

which is a nonlinear function of the distribution of .
This quantity is not interpretable and not stable, because:

E[e]E\left[e^{-\eta}\right]E[e]

depends heavily on variance in .

What is stable and meaningful?

The overall mean:

E[Y]E[Y]E[Y]

This is well-defined:

E[Y]=E[exp()].E[Y] = E[\exp(\eta)].E[Y]=E[exp()].

Given centered coding:

  • mean(effects) = 0

  • mean(s) = 0

Thus:

E[exp()]=exp()E[exp(effects)]E[exp(s)]E[\exp(\eta)] = \exp(\mu)\, E[\exp(\text{effects})]\, E[\exp(s)]E[exp()]=exp()E[exp(effects)]E[exp(s)]

and we can solve exactly for to achieve any target mean.

This matches what you do for Poisson and Log-normal.

Conclusion

Target overall mean(Y)

NOT rate.

Because:

TargetSensible?Why
Overall mean E[Y]E[Y]E[Y] YesWell-defined, stable, interpretable
Overall rate E[]=E[1/exp()]E[\lambda] = E[1/\exp(\eta)]E[]=E[1/exp()] NoNonlinear, distorted by effects & random effects
Average of cell rates NoDepends on coding and effect size, not meaningful

So the correct parameter to target in exponential-GLM simulations is:

Y\*=target mean\mu_Y^\* = \text{target mean}Y\*=target mean

and solve for accordingly.

ChatGPT said:

Yes exactly. For both Exponential (mean-parameterization) and Poisson you should target the overall mean (dataset-average mean), not an average rate or some other transformed quantity. With a centered design the solution is analytic and very simple.

Below are compact, ready-to-use R functions plus a short explanation and an example.

Why this works (short)

With your centered coding and subject random intercept sN(0,s2)s\sim N(0,\sigma_s^2)sN(0,s2),

=+effects+s,effects: a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2.\eta = \mu + \text{effects} + s, \qquad \text{effects: } a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + a_{12} x_1 x_2.=+effects+s,effects: a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2.

For log-link families (Poisson and Exponential mean-param.):

E[Yx]=exp(+effects)E[exp(s)]=exp(+effects)exp(12s2).E[Y\mid x] = \exp(\mu + \text{effects})\cdot E[\exp(s)] = \exp(\mu + \text{effects})\cdot \exp\!\Big(\tfrac12\sigma_s^2\Big).E[Yx]=exp(+effects)E[exp(s)]=exp(+effects)exp(21s2).

Average over the balanced design (vector of effects):

E[Y]=exp(+12s2)1Niexp(effectsi).\overline{E[Y]} = \exp\!\Big(\mu + \tfrac12\sigma_s^2\Big)\cdot \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i} \exp(\text{effects}_i).E[Y]=exp(+21s2)N1iexp(effectsi).

Solve for \mu:

=log(target_mean)12s2log(1Nieeffectsi).\mu = \log(\text{target\_mean}) - \tfrac12\sigma_s^2 - \log\Big(\frac{1}{N}\sum_i e^{\text{effects}_i}\Big).=log(target_mean)21s2log(N1ieeffectsi).

This formula is the same for Poisson (target mean = target ) and Exponential (target mean = 1/rate).

R functions

r
# compute effects vector from design + fixed effects
compute_effects <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0) {
  # design must have columns design$x1 and design$x2 (centered coding)
  with(design, a1 * x1 + a2 * x2 + a12 * (x1 * x2))
}

# generic mu for log-link families (Poisson, Exponential mean-param)
mu_loglink <- function(effects, sigma_s = 0, mean_target) {
  if (mean_target <= 0) stop("mean_target must be > 0")
  Ebar <- mean(exp(effects))
  mu <- log(mean_target) - 0.5 * sigma_s^2 - log(Ebar)
  mu
}

# convenience wrappers
mu_poisson <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0, sigma_s=0, lambda_target) {
  eff <- compute_effects(design, a1, a2, a12)
  mu_loglink(eff, sigma_s = sigma_s, mean_target = lambda_target)
}

mu_exponential <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0, sigma_s=0, rate_target = NULL, mean_target = NULL) {
  eff <- compute_effects(design, a1, a2, a12)
  if (!is.null(rate_target)) mean_target <- 1 / rate_target
  if (is.null(mean_target)) stop("Provide either mean_target or rate_target")
  mu_loglink(eff, sigma_s = sigma_s, mean_target = mean_target)
}

Example

r
# build a simple centered design: m1=2, m2=2, reps=3
coding <- function(nlevels) { levels <- sort(c(0,1, runif(nlevels-2))); levels - mean(levels) }
make_design <- function(m1, m2, reps=1) {
  x1v <- coding(m1); x2v <- coding(m2)
  expand.grid(x1 = x1v, x2 = x2v, rep = 1:reps, KEEP.OUT.ATTRS = FALSE)
}
design <- make_design(2, 2, reps = 3)

# choose effects and random-effect SD
a1 <- 0.5; a2 <- -0.2; a12 <- 0
sigma_s <- 0.6

# Poisson target mean (lambda)
lambda_target <- 2.5
mu_p <- mu_poisson(design, a1, a2, a12, sigma_s, lambda_target)
mu_p
# simulate (with n_subjects subjects)
nsubj <- 50
per_subj <- nrow(design)
subject <- rep(1:nsubj, each = per_subj)
svals <- rnorm(nsubj, 0, sigma_s)
effects <- compute_effects(design, a1, a2, a12)
eta <- mu_p + rep(effects, times = nsubj) + svals[subject]
y_pois <- rpois(length(eta), lambda = exp(eta))
mean(y_pois)   # should be close to lambda_target

# Exponential: target rate = 0.25 (mean = 4)
rate_target <- 0.25
mu_e <- mu_exponential(design, a1, a2, a12, sigma_s, rate_target = rate_target)
eta_e <- mu_e + rep(effects, times = nsubj) + svals[subject]
y_exp <- rexp(length(eta_e), rate = 1/exp(eta_e))
mean(y_exp)    # should be close to 1/rate_target = 4

Notes & caveats

  • The formula relies on centered coding (so mean(effects) = 0). If your coding is not centered, replace Ebar <- mean(exp(effects)) with the average over the actual design; the algebra still holds but will absorb the design mean.

  • This matches the overall marginal mean (averaged across design and random intercept distribution).

  • For Poisson, the target mean is the same as the target (rate parameter of Poisson). For Exponential, we use mean-targeting (mean = 1 / rate_target).

  • If you prefer to target marginal means per cell or other summaries, you must solve differently (numeric or per-cell adjustments).

  • produce a small wrapper that returns mu for a grid of (a1,a2,sigma_s, target) values for precomputing. Which next?

i want to verify whether these functions really produce poisson or exponential distributions. It does not seem so....
ChatGPT said:

You're absolutely right to check this carefully and yes, it can look like the data are not Poisson or not Exponential if you check them the wrong way.
But the functions are producing Poisson and Exponential distributions conditioned on .

The issue is:

Your simulation is generating mixtures of Poisson or Exponential distributions, not a single Poisson or Exponential distribution.

This is guaranteed to happen whenever varies across rows (due to fixed effects or random effects).

Let me make this absolutely clear.

1. Key concept: GLMs with log link generate mixtures

If:

YiiPoisson(i),i=exp(i)Y_i \mid \eta_i \sim \text{Poisson}(\lambda_i), \qquad \lambda_i = \exp(\eta_i)YiiPoisson(i),i=exp(i)

and varies across rows, then the unconditional distribution of Y is:

YiPoisson(i).Y \sim \sum_{i} \text{Poisson}(\lambda_i).YiPoisson(i).

A mixture of Poisson distributions is NOT Poisson unless all i\lambda_ii are equal.

Same for Exponential:

YiiExponential(mean=exp(i)).Y_i \mid \eta_i \sim \text{Exponential}(\text{mean} = \exp(\eta_i)).YiiExponential(mean=exp(i)).

If varies, the unconditional distribution is a mixture of exponentials, which is not exponential.

2. Why your diagnostic plots dont look exponential or Poisson

Example:

You check:

r
hist(y)
qqplot(....)

and you see departures from Poisson/Exponential.

This is expected.
It does not mean the simulation is wrong.

It means:

You are looking at a mixture, not at the conditional distribution.

If varies across conditions / subjects:

  • histogram becomes multi-modal or heavy-tailed

  • QQ-plot does not match a single exponential curve

  • variance > mean (for Poisson mixtures)

  • distribution looks fatter than exponential (for exponential mixtures)

This is correct behavior.

3. How to verify correctness properly

A. Check within a single cell

Pick one experimental cell where is constant. For example:

r
idx <- which(design$x1 == -0.5 & design$x2 == 0.5) 
y_cell <- Y[idx]

# check exponential
qqplot(rexp(10000, rate = 1/mean(exp(eta[idx]))), y_cell)

Within one cell, the distribution should look exponential or Poisson.

B. Check conditional on

For exponential:

r
rexp_test <- rexp(length(eta), rate = 1/exp(eta))
ks.test(Y, rexp_test)

This tests:

YiExponential(mean=exp(i)).Y_i \sim \text{Exponential(mean} = \exp(\eta_i)).YiExponential(mean=exp(i)).

For Poisson:

r
table(Y) / length(Y)
table(rpois(length(eta), lambda = exp(eta))) / length(eta)

They match conditionally.

C. Check that residual noise is exponential or Poisson

Define conditional means:

r
mu_i <- exp(eta)

For exponential:

r
eps <- Y / mu_i
qqplot(rexp(10000, 1), eps)     # should be roughly exponential(1)

Because:

Yi=iEi,EiExponential(1)Y_i = \mu_i \cdot E_i, \quad E_i \sim \text{Exponential}(1)Yi=iEi,EiExponential(1)

For Poisson:

Check conditional variance:

r
tapply(Y, eta, var)
tapply(Y, eta, mean)

Within each group, var mean.

4. Why mixtures look wrong (mathematical intuition)

Poisson mixture:

YiiPoisson(i)Y \sim \sum_i \pi_i\,\text{Poisson}(\lambda_i)YiiPoisson(i)

overdispersed (Var > Mean)
heavier tails
QQ-plot deviates strongly from Poisson

Exponential mixture:

YiiExponential(i)Y \sim \sum_i \pi_i\,\text{Exponential}(\mu_i)YiiExponential(i)

convex combination of exponentials
heavier tail than exponential
curve bends above the exponential line in QQ-plots

This is normal.

5. Conclusion

The mu_poisson() and mu_exponential() functions are correct.

Your simulation is generating Poisson and Exponential distributions

conditionally on which is what a GLM is defined to do.

The unconditional marginal distribution is a mixture, and therefore:

  • not Poisson

  • not single-parameter exponential

So your diagnostic plots must be conditional, not unconditional.

Good that helps. The reason your per-condition histogram still may not look like a single Poisson or Exponential is almost always one of these two:

  1. Per condition (e.g. x1 > 0) usually still mixes over different values of because it includes multiple subjects (different random intercepts) and/or different levels of the other factor(s). A mixture of Poissons or Exponentials is not a single Poisson/Exponential.

1) Quick check: are you mixing different within your subset?

2) Correct conditional checks

A Poisson: check at fixed (x1, x2, subject)

You need multiple replicate observations in the same cell for the same subject (i.e. r > 1) to see the Poisson empirically. If your design has r replicates per cell per subject, do:

r
# choose one cell and one subject that has >1 replicate

# inspect
table(cell_rows$Y)

# overlay theoretical Poisson probs on histogram

     freq = TRUE, main = "Per-subject, per-cell Poisson check")
xvals <- min(cell_rows$Y):max(cell_rows$Y)
lines(xvals, dpois(xvals, lambda0) * nrow(cell_rows), type = "h", col = "red", lwd=3)

If you do not have multiple replicates per subject/cell (r=1), you cannot check empirical distribution at that conditioning level you must use PIT or aggregate-check (below).

Poisson PIT (randomized PIT for discrete)

Compute randomized PIT for each observation and check uniformity:

r
# vector of lambdas (one per obs)
lam <- exp(df_poisson$eta)

# randomized PIT
u_poiss <- ppois(df_poisson$Y - 1, lam) + runif(nrow(df_poisson)) * dpois(df_poisson$Y, lam)

# QQ plot against uniform or normal (z = qnorm(u))
qqplot(qunif(ppoints(nrow(df_poisson))), sort(u_poiss), main = "Randomized PIT (Poisson)")
abline(0,1,col="red")
# or normal QQ of z:
qqnorm(qnorm(u_poiss)); abline(0,1,col="red")

If your model is correctly generating Y ~ Poisson(lambda = exp(eta)), the PIT u_poiss should be ~ Uniform(0,1).

B Exponential: check at fixed (x1, x2, subject) or use PIT

If you have multiple replicates per subject/cell:

r
cell_rows <- subset(df_exponential, x1 == some_x1 & x2 == some_x2 & subject == some_subject)
meanY <- mean(cell_rows$Y)     # empirical mean for that subject+cell
# theoretical mean = exp(eta)
mean_theor <- mean(exp(cell_rows$eta))  # or exp(eta[1]) if identical
# check scaled variable should be Exp(1)
z <- cell_rows$Y / mean_theor
qqplot(qexp(ppoints(length(z)), rate=1), sort(z), main="Exp(1) QQ for scaled Y")
abline(0,1,col="red")

If r=1 or you mix subjects, use the PIT for continuous:

r
mu_vec <- exp(df_exponential$eta)    # conditional means
u_exp <- 1 - exp(- df_exponential$Y / mu_vec)   # PIT, should be U(0,1)
qqplot(qunif(ppoints(nrow(df_exponential))), sort(u_exp), main="PIT for Exponential")
abline(0,1,col="red")

3) Aggregate tests you can run if you cannot condition down to single

If you have only one replicate per subject/cell, you can still test correctness using the conditional probabilities/lambdas:

Poisson: compare observed counts to expected using simulation envelopes

r
# simulate many replicates of the whole dataset from the conditional lambdas
B <- 2000
sim_means <- numeric(B)
obs <- df_poisson$Y
lam <- exp(df_poisson$eta)
sim_counts <- matrix(NA, nrow=length(lam), ncol=B)
for (b in 1:B) {
  sim_counts[,b] <- rpois(length(lam), lam)
}
# compare distribution of some statistic, e.g., overall mean
sim_mean <- colMeans(sim_counts)
mean(obs); quantile(sim_mean, c(0.025, 0.975))
# or per-cell comparisons etc.

Exponential: do the same using rexp(n, rate = 1/mu) with mu = exp(eta)

4) Common pitfalls checklist

  • Are you conditioning only on x1 > 0? That usually mixes multiple x2 levels and many subjects mixture.

  • Do you have random intercepts? Then even within (x1,x2) the lambdas/means differ across subjects.

  • Do you have replicates per subjectcell? If not, you need PIT or simulation envelope tests rather than per-cell histograms.

A mixture of Poissons is NOT Poisson.

Explanation of why your simulation is correct

Given your code, the underlying model is exactly:

YijkijkPoisson(ijk)Y_{ijk} \mid \eta_{ijk} \sim \text{Poisson}(\lambda_{ijk})YijkijkPoisson(ijk) ijk=exp(ijk)\lambda_{ijk} = \exp(\eta_{ijk})ijk=exp(ijk) ijk=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j+sk.\eta_{ijk} = \mu + a_1 x_{1i} + a_2 x_{2j} + a_{12} x_{1i}x_{2j} + s_k.ijk=+a1x1i+a2x2j+a12x1ix2j+sk.

This is the canonical log-link Poisson GLMM, so the conditional distribution is Poisson.

But marginally (after mixing over s) it becomes a Poisson-lognormal mixture, which is not Poisson.

This is why your histograms dont match Poisson.

ChatGPT said:

Good youre right that sigma_s = 1 is very large for many Poisson/Exponential setups. Below I explain why, give the exact formulas that show how _s inflates means and variances, show numeric examples, and give short R snippets so you can pick a reasonable _s (or compute the _s that yields a desired overdispersion).

Quick intuition (one line)

A normal random intercept sN(0,s2)s \sim N(0,\sigma_s^2)sN(0,s2) acts multiplicatively on the mean because =exp(+effects+s)\lambda=\exp(\mu+\text{effects}+s)=exp(+effects+s). So even modest s\sigma_ss produces substantial multiplicative variation: E[exp(s)]=exp(12s2)\mathbb{E}[\exp(s)] = \exp(\tfrac12\sigma_s^2)E[exp(s)]=exp(21s2).

Exact useful formulas (Poisson / log-link)

Let i=exp(i)\lambda_i = \exp(\eta_i)i=exp(i) with i=+effectsi+sk\eta_i = \mu + \text{effects}_i + s_ki=+effectsi+sk, skN(0,s2)s_k\sim N(0,\sigma_s^2)skN(0,s2).

  • Conditional mean: E[Yii]=i\mathbb{E}[Y_i\mid\eta_i]=\lambda_iE[Yii]=i.

  • Marginal (over s) mean of \lambda for a fixed cell with fixed effects value eee:

    Es[]=exp(e+)exp(12s2).\mathbb{E}_s[\lambda] = \exp(e + \mu)\,\exp\!\Big(\tfrac12\sigma_s^2\Big).Es[]=exp(e+)exp(21s2).

  • If you average across the balanced design, let E=1Nieeffectsi\bar E = \frac{1}{N}\sum_i e^{\text{effects}_i}E=N1ieeffectsi. Then the dataset average mean

    =exp(+12s2)E.\overline{\lambda} = \exp\!\Big(\mu + \tfrac12\sigma_s^2\Big)\,\bar E.=exp(+21s2)E.

    (This is what mu_loglink() uses to solve for \mu.)

  • Marginal variance of YYY (the mixture variance) at an observation:

    Var(Y)=E[]Poisson part+Var()overdispersion from s.\operatorname{Var}(Y) = \underbrace{\mathbb{E}[\lambda]}_{\text{Poisson part}} + \underbrace{\operatorname{Var}(\lambda)}_{\text{overdispersion from }s}.Var(Y)=Poisson partE[]+overdispersion from sVar().

    If =exp(s)\lambda=\alpha\cdot\exp(s)=exp(s) ( = exp(+effects) constant within group), then

    Var()=2(exp(s2)1),\operatorname{Var}(\lambda) = \alpha^2(\exp(\sigma_s^2)-1),Var()=2(exp(s2)1),

    and therefore

    Var(Y)E[Y]=1+(exp(s2)1).\frac{\operatorname{Var}(Y)}{\mathbb{E}[Y]} \;=\; 1 \;+\; \alpha\big(\exp(\sigma_s^2)-1\big).E[Y]Var(Y)=1+(exp(s2)1).

    If you want the global Var/Mean, replace by the relevant average \overline{\lambda} or compute per-cell.

Numeric examples (illustrative assume target mean 5)

Take a representative conditional mean 5\alpha \approx 55. Compute:

  • exp(12s2)\exp(\tfrac12\sigma_s^2)exp(21s2) multiplicative factor on mean

  • exp(s2)1\exp(\sigma_s^2)-1exp(s2)1 fractional extra variance factor of

  • Var/Mean = 1+(exp(s2)1)1 + \alpha(\exp(\sigma_s^2)-1)1+(exp(s2)1)

_sexp() (mean factor)exp()-1Var/Mean (=5)
0.01.00000.00001.00
0.21.02020.04081 + 50.0408 = 1.204
0.51.13310.28401 + 50.2840 = 2.420
1.01.64871.71831 + 51.7183 = 9.5915

So _s = 1 yields huge overdispersion: Var/Mean 9.6 when mean 5. _s = 0.2 yields a mild overdispersion 1.2 (often realistic). _s = 0.5 already produces Var/Mean 2.4 (substantial).

How to pick _s in practice

  • If you want near-Poisson behavior (Var Mean), choose _s 0.2 for means around 110.

  • If you want modest overdispersion (Var/Mean 1.21.5), _s 0.150.3 is reasonable.

  • For strong between-subject heterogeneity, use _s 0.5 expect large overdispersion.

  • If the mean is small (e.g. 0.1), the same _s causes less absolute overdispersion because is small; Var/Mean depends on (exp()-1).

A practical workflow: pick a desired Var/Mean (overdispersion) and compute _s that achieves it (closed-form).

Compute _s from a target overdispersion (Var/Mean)

From

OD:=Var(Y)E[Y]=1+(exp(s2)1),\text{OD} := \frac{\operatorname{Var}(Y)}{\mathbb{E}[Y]} = 1 + \alpha(\exp(\sigma_s^2)-1),OD:=E[Y]Var(Y)=1+(exp(s2)1),

solve for _s:

exp(s2)1=OD1s=log(1+OD1).\exp(\sigma_s^2)-1 = \frac{\text{OD}-1}{\alpha} \quad\Rightarrow\quad \sigma_s = \sqrt{\log\!\Big(1 + \frac{\text{OD}-1}{\alpha}\Big)}.exp(s2)1=OD1s=log(1+OD1).

If you want OD for the dataset average, use =\alpha = \overline{\lambda}= (the average mean), not the conditional in a single cell.

R code diagnostics and helper functions

r
# compute Var/Mean for given sigma_s and representative mean alpha
vm_overdispersion <- function(alpha, sigma_s) {
  1 + alpha * (exp(sigma_s^2) - 1)
}

# compute sigma_s that yields desired OD for a given alpha
sigma_s_for_OD <- function(alpha, OD) {
  if (OD <= 1) return(0)
  sigma2 <- log(1 + (OD - 1) / alpha)
  if (sigma2 < 0) stop("No solution (check OD and alpha)")
  sqrt(sigma2)
}

# examples
alpha <- 5
sigs <- c(0, 0.2, 0.5, 1.0)
data.frame(sigma_s = sigs,
           mean_factor = exp(0.5 * sigs^2),
           exp_sigma2_minus1 = exp(sigs^2)-1,
           Var_over_Mean = vm_overdispersion(alpha, sigs))
# compute sigma to get OD = 1.2 when alpha = 5
sigma_s_for_OD(5, 1.2)   #  0.198

Practical recommendations for your simulation

  • If you want to see Poisson-like histograms per condition (i.e. not huge mixtures), either:

    • reduce sigma_s (e.g. 0.10.3), or

    • increase number of replicates per subject and condition and visually check within-subject per-cell replicates (as you did).

  • If you need a specific overdispersion (Var/Mean), use sigma_s_for_OD() to pick sigma_s.

  • Always remember to recompute (the intercept) after changing sigma_s so your dataset-average mean remains the target (use the mu_loglink() formula you already have).

If you want Var/Mean 1.2 (mild overdispersion), solve:

# sigma_needed  0.198

Then set sigma_s = 0.20, recompute mu with mu_loglink(...), and re-simulate.

Which would you like?

You said:
OK, but does this mean that for each distribution i simulate (Poisson, exponential, binomial, etc.) I should assign a different sigma_s? How do I justify this?
ChatGPT said:

Short answer: No, you should not use the same across all distributions unless you intentionally want the **same amount of subject heterogeneity on the -scale (the linear predictor scale).
But if instead you want the same heterogeneity on the observed data scale (same amount of overdispersion or same CV), then yes, must differ by distribution.

And this is perfectly justified because latent-scale heterogeneity transforms differently for different link functions and distributions.

Below is the full explanation in a way that is publishable.

Key principle

A subject random effect skN(0,s2)s_k\sim N(0,\sigma_s^2)skN(0,s2) acts on the linear predictor , not directly on the observed outcome. The way this heterogeneity shows up on the data scale depends on:

  1. the link function,

  2. the curvature of the inverse link,

  3. the distribution family.

Thus:

  • With the log link (Poisson, Exponential, Log-normal),

    =exp()\lambda = \exp(\eta)=exp()

    heterogeneity becomes multiplicative, producing overdispersion.

  • With the logit link (Binomial),

    p=logit1()p = \text{logit}^{-1}(\eta)p=logit1()

    heterogeneity is S-shaped, saturating near 0 or 1, reducing variance asymmetrically.

  • With the identity link (Gaussian),
    heterogeneity stays additive.

Because these transformations differ, using the same produces completely different amounts of variability at the observable level.

Therefore:

It is not conceptually correct to force the same across unrelated distributions.

It is conceptually correct to choose separately for each family so that the data-scale heterogeneity matches your scientific goals.

This is exactly how simulation papers are normally written.

Justification you can write in your paper

Here is a clean, correct wording:

Because the random subject effect acts on the linear predictor scale, its impact on the observed data depends on the distribution family and link function.
For example, a normal random intercept with variance induces multiplicative variation under a log link (Poisson, Exponential) and S-shaped probability distortion under a logit link (Binomial), leading to different amounts of overdispersion on the data scale.

Therefore, to simulate comparable levels of between-subject variability across distributions, we calibrated separately for each family so that the resulting data-scale dispersion (e.g., meanvariance ratio or average probability variability) matched pre-specified targets.
This ensures that the simulation conditions across models are comparable and interpretable.

This is exactly the usual justification.

How to choose per distribution

You choose based on what you want to control on the data scale.

If you want to control:

1. The meanvariance ratio

Applies to Poisson, Exponential, other log-scale distributions.
Use formula:

Var(Y)E[Y]=1+(exp(s2)1).\frac{\mathrm{Var}(Y)}{\mathbb{E}[Y]} = 1 + \lambda(\exp(\sigma_s^2) - 1).E[Y]Var(Y)=1+(exp(s2)1).

Solve for to achieve desired OD.

2. The average probability

Applies to Binomial.
We already derived:

E[p]=logit1(1+2s23)\mathbb{E}[p] = \text{logit}^{-1}\big(\mu_\eta \sqrt{1+\tfrac{\pi^2\sigma_s^2}{3}}\big)E[p]=logit1(1+32s2)

Adjustment needed.

3. The overall mean

For Exponential, Poisson, Log-normal, we solved based on to maintain target mean.

4. The CV (coefficient of variation)

Easy to target for lognormal;
Harder but possible for Poisson or Exponential.

Thus:

  • For each distribution, you pick such that the observable variability matches your scenario.

  • That is the correct statistical practice.

How to present this in one simple statement

Heres the shortest scientific justification:

Because the random intercept operates on the linear predictor scale, different distribution families transform this variability differently. To ensure comparable levels of observable heterogeneity across models, was calibrated separately for each family to yield the desired distributional characteristics (e.g., mean, meanvariance ratio, or average probability).

Thats all reviewers need to hear.

If you want one unified for all distributions

There is a way, but only if you decide to treat as heterogeneity on the latent -scale, not the observable scale.

That means:

  • You accept different amounts of overdispersion for Poisson/exponential vs probability-range compression for Binomial.

  • It is scientifically OK only if your research question is about linear-predictor heterogeneity.

Then you justify:

We imposed the same across models because we define subject variability at the level of the linear predictor. Different families therefore yield different observable-scale variability, reflecting the natural impact of the link function.

This is also acceptable if transparently stated.

Final recommendation (for serious simulation work)

I recommend:

You target the data-scale phenomena you care about

(e.g., average rate, average probability, overdispersion)

Then compute separately per distribution to achieve those targets.

This yields the most interpretable and fair comparisons across models.

2 R Code Framework

We can build per-distribution calibration functions and utilities.

r
# Centered coding helper
coding <- function(nlevels) { 
  levels <- sort(c(0,1, runif(nlevels-2)))
  levels - mean(levels)
}

# Compute fixed effects contribution
compute_effects <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0) {
  with(design, a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*(x1*x2))
}

# ---------------------------------------------
# Poisson / Exponential (log-link)
mu_loglink <- function(effects, sigma_s=0, mean_target) {
  if (mean_target <= 0) stop("mean_target must be > 0")
  Ebar <- mean(exp(effects))
  mu <- log(mean_target) - 0.5*sigma_s^2 - log(Ebar)
  mu
}

# Poisson wrapper
mu_poisson <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0, sigma_s=0, mean_target) {
  eff <- compute_effects(design, a1, a2, a12)
  mu_loglink(eff, sigma_s, mean_target)
}

# Exponential wrapper
mu_exponential <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0, sigma_s=0, mean_target) {
  eff <- compute_effects(design, a1, a2, a12)
  mu_loglink(eff, sigma_s, mean_target)
}

# ---------------------------------------------
# Binomial (size>1), target average p
library(stats)

mu_binomial <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0, sigma_s=0, p_target, size=1) {
  eff <- compute_effects(design, a1, a2, a12)
  
  f <- function(mu) {
    # approximate marginal mean using logistic-normal
    eta <- mu + eff
    # if sigma_s>0, integrate over random effect (approx. using logistic-normal variance)
    approx_p <- mean(plogis(eta / sqrt(1 + (pi^2/3)*sigma_s^2)))
    approx_p - p_target
  }
  uniroot(f, interval=c(-10,10))$root
}

# ---------------------------------------------
# Log-normal (target mean and SD)
mu_lognormal <- function(mean_target, sd_target) {
  sigma2 <- log(1 + (sd_target^2)/(mean_target^2))
  mu <- log(mean_target) - 0.5*sigma2
  list(mu=mu, sigma=sqrt(sigma2))
}

# ---------------------------------------------
# Cauchy (x0=0, target gamma)
mu_cauchy <- function(gamma_target) {
  list(x0=0, gamma=gamma_target)
}

# ---------------------------------------------
# Optional: compute sigma_s for desired overdispersion (Poisson/Exponential)
sigma_s_for_OD <- function(alpha, OD) {
  if (OD <= 1) return(0)
  sqrt(log(1 + (OD-1)/alpha))
}

# Example usage:
# design <- expand.grid(x1=c(-0.5,0.5), x2=c(-0.5,0.5))
# mu_p <- mu_poisson(design, a1=1, sigma_s=0.2, mean_target=5)

Notes for simulation

  1. Use per-distribution to control observable-scale heterogeneity.

  2. Recompute after changing to maintain target mean or probability.

  3. Random effects are added on (log scale for log-link, identity for Gaussian, etc.).

  4. Binomial requires numerical solver to match average probability.

  5. Log-normal directly converts target mean/SD into and .

  6. Cauchy: only location x and scale matter; random effects add extra tail fattening.

ChatGPT said:

Ah thats the key question! Let me explain carefully.

1 What OD (overdispersion) means here

For Poisson and Exponential (log-link), the latent subject random effect skN(0,s2)s_k \sim N(0, \sigma_s^2)skN(0,s2) produces extra variability in the observed data.

For Poisson:

YijkPoisson(ijk),ijk=exp(ijk),ijk=+effects+skY_{ijk} \sim \text{Poisson}(\lambda_{ijk}), \quad \lambda_{ijk} = \exp(\eta_{ijk}), \quad \eta_{ijk} = \mu + \text{effects} + s_kYijkPoisson(ijk),ijk=exp(ijk),ijk=+effects+sk

Then the marginal variance of Y (over s) is:

Var(Y)=E[]Poisson variance+Var()extra variance from s\text{Var}(Y) = \underbrace{\mathbb{E}[\lambda]}_{\text{Poisson variance}} + \underbrace{\text{Var}(\lambda)}_{\text{extra variance from s}}Var(Y)=Poisson varianceE[]+extra variance from sVar()

and the overdispersion factor is:

OD:=Var(Y)E[Y]=1+Var()E[]=1+(exp(s2)1)\text{OD} := \frac{\text{Var}(Y)}{\mathbb{E}[Y]} = 1 + \frac{\text{Var}(\lambda)}{\mathbb{E}[\lambda]} = 1 + \alpha (\exp(\sigma_s^2)-1)OD:=E[Y]Var(Y)=1+E[]Var()=1+(exp(s2)1)

where \alpha \approx \lambda is the mean in that cell.

2 What value should you use for OD?

  • OD = 1 no extra variance, i.e., = 0 standard Poisson / Exponential.

  • OD > 1 extra variability from subject random effects (common in real data).

So OD is how much variance you want at the data level, relative to the Poisson variance:

  • Mild overdispersion: OD 1.2 1.5

  • Moderate: OD 2

  • Strong: OD 5 10 ( = 1, which you tried, produces very strong overdispersion).

Example: if your target mean 5:

  • OD = 1.2 Var(Y) 6 slightly overdispersed

  • OD = 2 Var(Y) 10 noticeably overdispersed

  • OD = 10 Var(Y) 50 extremely overdispersed ( 1)

3 How to convert OD to

From earlier formula:

s=log(1+OD1)\sigma_s = \sqrt{\log\Big(1 + \frac{\text{OD}-1}{\alpha}\Big)}s=log(1+OD1)

Example in R:

r
alpha <- 5       # representative mean per cell
OD <- 1.2        # desired overdispersion (Var/Mean)
sigma_s <- sqrt(log(1 + (OD-1)/alpha))
sigma_s
#  0.198, mild overdispersion

4 Choosing OD in practice

  • If you want the simulation to look nearly Poisson/Exponential use OD 1.0 1.2

  • If you want noticeable subject heterogeneity OD 1.5 2

  • If you want very strong variability OD 3 10

Important: OD depends on the mean in the cell, so for Poisson or Exponential mean 5, OD = 1.2 gives 0.2; for 1, 0.45.

5 Summary / Rule of Thumb

  • OD is the variance-to-mean ratio you want after adding subject random effects.

  • Pick it based on how much heterogeneity you want in your simulation.

  • Then compute using the formula.

  • This ensures that your latent produces the desired observable-scale variability.

If you want, I can make a small table showing values for Poisson/Exponential for typical = 1, 5, 10 and OD = 1.1, 1.2, 1.5, 2, 5. This is often very handy for designing simulations.

for binomial and lognormal is overdispersion an issue or not? should i callibrate as well?
ChatGPT said:

Good question lets go distribution by distribution.

1 Binomial (size > 1)

  • The binomial variance is already constrained:

Var(Y)=np(1p)\text{Var}(Y) = n p (1-p)Var(Y)=np(1p)

  • Overdispersion only occurs if you add extra random effects on the linear predictor ( = + effects + s_k).

  • So:

    • If you want the Binomial to behave exactly like standard binomial set = 0.

    • If you want subject heterogeneity, then > 0 extra variation on the observed proportion (overdispersion).

  • Calibration is needed only if you want a specific average probability AND specific between-subject heterogeneity.

  • Note: if p_target is very close to 0 or 1, cannot be large, because the logistic transformation saturates.

Rule of thumb: calibrate for Binomial if you want realistic subject heterogeneity; otherwise = 0 is fine.

2 Log-normal

  • You directly specify mean and SD on the observed scale.

  • Random effects (subject heterogeneity) can be added on the log-scale:

Y=exp(+sk+)Y = \exp(\eta + s_k + \epsilon)Y=exp(+sk+)

  • Here, overdispersion is built-in because you already control SD.

  • If you add extra on the log-scale, it will increase the observed SD / CV.

Rule of thumb: if you already target mean and SD on the observed scale, you dont need extra unless you want additional subject heterogeneity beyond the specified SD.

3 Practical guidance for your simulation framework

DistributionOverdispersion / Recommendation
Poissonyespick OD > 1 compute using _s = sqrt(log(1 + (OD-1)/))
Exponentialyessame as Poisson, pick OD
Binomialoptionallycalibrate if you want subject heterogeneity; otherwise = 0
Log-normalno (mean & SD specified) optional; use only if extra subject heterogeneity is desired
Cauchyyes, heavy tails can be added for extra subject heterogeneity; x and fixed

Takeaway

  • Poisson / Exponential / Cauchy: strongly affects variance calibrate for desired overdispersion.

  • Binomial: affects observed probability variation calibrate only if heterogeneity is desired.

  • Log-normal: adds extra multiplicative variation calibrate only if you want more than the specified SD.

1 Binomial (size > 1, logit link)

  • Latent linear predictor:

=+a1x1+a2x2+sk,skN(0,s2)\eta = \mu + a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + s_k, \quad s_k \sim N(0, \sigma_s^2)=+a1x1+a2x2+sk,skN(0,s2)

  • Observed probability:

p=logit1()p = \text{logit}^{-1}(\eta)p=logit1()

  • = 1 very strong heterogeneity on the probability scale, because:

    • Logistic curve saturates: a 3 swing maps almost to p 0 or p 1.

    • Even if mean p 0.10.2, = 1 produces many subjects with p 0.001 and p 0.9.

    • This is usually unrealistically extreme.

Rule of thumb: for Binomial, 0.1 0.3 is already noticeable heterogeneity; = 1 is probably too large unless you want almost all-or-none subjects.

  • You can check this numerically:

r
sigma_s <- 1
eta <- qlogis(0.1) + rnorm(1000, 0, sigma_s)
p <- plogis(eta)
summary(p)
hist(p)

  • Youll see a huge spread: many p near 0 or 1.

2 Log-normal (log-link)

  • Latent linear predictor on log-scale:

log(Y)=+a1x1+a2x2+sk+,skN(0,s2),N(0,2)\log(Y) = \mu + a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + s_k + \epsilon, \quad s_k \sim N(0, \sigma_s^2), \epsilon \sim N(0, \sigma_\epsilon^2)log(Y)=+a1x1+a2x2+sk+,skN(0,s2),N(0,2)

  • = 1 multiplicative heterogeneity:

CVsubject=exp(s2)11.317\text{CV}_{\text{subject}} = \sqrt{\exp(\sigma_s^2) - 1} \approx 1.317CVsubject=exp(s2)11.317

  • So each subject varies roughly 130% around its mean.

  • Depending on your target SD, this may be very large. For realistic data, 0.10.5 is more typical.

Conclusion

  • Binomial: = 1 huge spread on probability scale, likely unrealistic. Consider 0.10.3.

  • Log-normal: = 1 CV 1.3, i.e., very strong multiplicative heterogeneity. Depending on your target SD, this may be too large; 0.20.5 is often enough.

Rule of thumb:

  • = 0.1 mild heterogeneity

  • = 0.3 noticeable heterogeneity

  • = 1 extreme heterogeneity (often unrealistic for Binomial, sometimes acceptable for Log-normal if extreme variability is desired).

We just need to define what OD means for each distribution:

DistributionObservable OD definitionFormula linking to OD
PoissonVar(Y)/E(Y)OD = 1 + *(exp()-1) = log(1 + (OD-1)/)
ExponentialVar(Y)/E(Y) (CV)OD = 1 + on log-scale? Actually: CV = exp()-1 = log(OD + 1)

  • Cauchy variance is technically infinite; use scale as proxy.

R code to generate from target OD

r
# ---------- Poisson ----------
sigma_s_poisson <- function(lambda, OD) {
  if(OD <= 1) return(0)
  sqrt(log(1 + (OD-1)/lambda))
}

# ---------- Exponential ----------
sigma_s_exponential <- function(OD) {
  if(OD <= 1) return(0)
  sqrt(log(OD))
}

# ---------- Normal ----------
sigma_s_normal <- function(sigma_e, OD) {
  sqrt((OD-1)*sigma_e^2)
}

# ---------- Log-normal ----------
sigma_s_lognormal <- function(OD) {
  sqrt(log(OD + 1))
}

# ---------- Binomial ----------
sigma_s_binomial <- function(n, p_target, OD) {
  # approximate: simulate p, then use uniroot to find  that gives OD
  f <- function(s) {
    p <- plogis(qlogis(p_target) + rnorm(100000,0,s))
    var(p)/ (p_target*(1-p_target)) - OD
  }
  uniroot(f, c(0,5))$root
}

# ---------- Cauchy ----------
sigma_s_cauchy <- function(OD) {
  # approximate: assume  adds multiplicative scale
  sqrt(OD - 1)
}

# Example table for OD = 1.2, =5, p=0.2, n=20
lambda <- 5
p_target <- 0.2
sigma_e <- 1
OD <- 1.2

data.frame(
  Distribution = c("Poisson","Exponential","Normal","Log-normal","Binomial","Cauchy"),
  sigma_s = c(
    sigma_s_poisson(lambda, OD),
    sigma_s_exponential(OD),
    sigma_s_normal(sigma_e, OD),
    sigma_s_lognormal(OD),
    sigma_s_binomial(n=20,p_target,OD),
    sigma_s_cauchy(OD)
  )
)

Interpretation

  • Now you can specify the desired overdispersion OD for each distribution.

  • The code returns on the latent scale needed to produce that OD.

  • Poisson / Exponential / Log-normal / Normal analytic.

  • Binomial numeric approximation.

  • Cauchy rough approximation via scale.

Do you want me to do that next?

You said:
Error in uniroot(f, c(0, 5)) : f() values at end points not of opposite sign
ChatGPT said:

Ah that error happens because the function youre passing to uniroot() does not cross zero in the interval [0,5].

For your sigma_s_binomial() function:

r
f <- function(s) {
  p <- plogis(qlogis(p_target) + rnorm(100000,0,s))
  var(p)/ (p_target*(1-p_target)) - OD
}

The problem:

  1. OD might be too large for the given p_target there is a maximum variance you can get for a probability.

    • Variance of a Bernoulli probability is p*(1-p).

    • If OD > 1, for p very small (like 0.05), you cannot reach that OD, no matter how large is.

  2. Random simulation noise can make f(s) not cross zero in [0,5].

Fixes / Options

Option 1: Check maximum achievable OD

r
max_OD <- function(p_target, n=1) {
  p <- plogis(qlogis(p_target) + rnorm(1e6,0,10)) # very large 
  var(p) / (p_target*(1-p_target))
}

  • If your desired OD > max_OD(p_target), uniroot() will fail its impossible.

Option 2: Use smaller OD or increase interval

r
sigma_s_binomial <- function(n, p_target, OD, max_s = 10) {
  f <- function(s) {
    p <- plogis(qlogis(p_target) + rnorm(100000,0,s))
    var(p)/ (p_target*(1-p_target)) - OD
  }
  # check if OD is achievable
  OD_max <- f(max_s) + OD
  if(f(0) * f(max_s) > 0) stop("OD not achievable: try smaller OD or increase max_s")
  uniroot(f, c(0, max_s))$root
}

  • This checks whether the root exists and allows you to increase the search interval.

Option 3: Use a deterministic approximation instead of simulation

  • For small p_target, variance of the logit-normal is roughly:

Var(p)p2(1p)212s2(complicated)\text{Var}(p) \approx \frac{p^2 (1-p)^2}{1 - 2\sigma_s^2 \cdots} \quad \text{(complicated)}Var(p)12s2p2(1p)2(complicated)

  • For simplicity, using simulation with large enough range usually works.

Practical advice

  1. For Binomial probabilities near 0 or 1, OD > 1 is often impossible, because p cannot exceed [0,1].

  2. 0.10.3 is usually enough for realistic heterogeneity.

  3. If you try OD too high (e.g., OD = 2 with p_target = 0.05), uniroot() will always fail thats not a coding bug, its mathematically impossible.

  • Automatically checks whether the target OD is achievable

  • Returns either or a warning that the OD is too high

  • Uses a large simulation interval safely

You said:
ok, for lognormal it proposes 0.88 and for normal 0.45?
ChatGPT said:

Yes that makes sense, and heres why. Lets break it down carefully.

1 Log-normal

  • Target: Var(Y)/E[Y]2=OD\text{Var}(Y)/\mathbb{E}[Y]^2 = \text{OD}Var(Y)/E[Y]2=OD

  • Formula for log-normal CV:

CV2=Var(Y)E[Y]2=exp(s2)1\text{CV}^2 = \frac{\text{Var}(Y)}{\mathbb{E}[Y]^2} = \exp(\sigma_s^2) - 1CV2=E[Y]2Var(Y)=exp(s2)1

  • Solve for :

s=log(OD+1)\sigma_s = \sqrt{\log(\text{OD} + 1)}s=log(OD+1)

  • If OD = 1.2:

s=log(1.2+1)=log(2.2)0.7880.888\sigma_s = \sqrt{\log(1.2 + 1)} = \sqrt{\log(2.2)} \approx \sqrt{0.788} \approx 0.888s=log(1.2+1)=log(2.2)0.7880.888

Exactly what you see.

  • Interpretation: a log-normal 0.88 produces a CV (exp(0.88)-1) 0.48. This is very high variability.

2 Normal

  • Latent SD: = 1

  • Overdispersion: OD = Var(Y)/Var() Var(Y) = OD * Var()

  • Additive on top of residual:

Var(Y)=2+s2=OD2\text{Var}(Y) = \sigma_\epsilon^2 + \sigma_s^2 = \text{OD} * \sigma_\epsilon^2Var(Y)=2+s2=OD2

  • Solve for :

s=Var(Y)2=(OD1)2\sigma_s = \sqrt{\text{Var}(Y) - \sigma_\epsilon^2} = \sqrt{(OD-1)\sigma_\epsilon^2}s=Var(Y)2=(OD1)2

  • If OD = 1.2 and = 1:

s=1.21=0.20.447\sigma_s = \sqrt{1.2 - 1} = \sqrt{0.2} \approx 0.447s=1.21=0.20.447

Exactly what you see.

  • Interpretation: an extra 0.45 adds moderate subject heterogeneity on top of residual SD = 1.

Takeaways

  • Log-normal: multiplicative effect higher needed to achieve same relative OD.

  • Normal: additive effect smaller sufficient for same OD.

  • This is exactly why latent-scale is distribution-dependent.

If you want, I can make a full table showing for all distributions (Normal, Log-normal, Poisson, Exponential, Binomial, Cauchy) for several OD values like 1.1, 1.2, 1.5, 2 so you can pick reasonable for each simulation scenario.

ChatGPT said:

Great! Heres a full reference table for calibration across distributions, for several common overdispersion values (OD).

Assumptions for the table:

  • Normal: residual SD = 1

  • Log-normal / Exponential: mean = 1

  • Poisson: = 5

  • Binomial: n = 20, p_target = 0.2 (approximate using simulation)

  • Cauchy: scale = 1, x = 0 (approximate)

R code to generate the table

r
set.seed(123)

# OD values
OD_values <- c(1.1, 1.2, 1.5, 2, 5)

# Preallocate
res <- data.frame(OD = OD_values,
                  sigma_normal = NA,
                  sigma_lognormal = NA,
                  sigma_poisson = NA,
                  sigma_exponential = NA,
                  sigma_binomial = NA,
                  sigma_cauchy = NA)

lambda <- 5
sigma_e <- 1
p_target <- 0.2
n_bin <- 20
gamma <- 1

for(i in seq_along(OD_values)) {
  OD <- OD_values[i]
  # Normal
  res$sigma_normal[i] <- sqrt((OD-1)*sigma_e^2)
  # Log-normal
  res$sigma_lognormal[i] <- sqrt(log(OD + 1))
  # Poisson
  res$sigma_poisson[i] <- if(OD <=1) 0 else sqrt(log(1 + (OD-1)/lambda))
  # Exponential
  res$sigma_exponential[i] <- if(OD <=1) 0 else sqrt(log(OD))
  # Binomial (numerical)
  f_bin <- function(s) {
    p <- plogis(qlogis(p_target) + rnorm(1e5,0,s))
    var(p)/(p_target*(1-p_target)) - OD
  }
  # check if achievable
  tryCatch({
    res$sigma_binomial[i] <- uniroot(f_bin, c(0,5))$root
  }, error=function(e) { res$sigma_binomial[i] <- NA })
  # Cauchy (rough)
  res$sigma_cauchy[i] <- sqrt(OD - 1)
}

res
