You said:
For the mu_binomial, you gave me two solutions, where the one uses plogis while the other uses integration. They do not give the same result. Which one is correct or more precise?
ChatGPT said:

Good question and an important one. The two ways you saw are not equivalent:

  • the plogis(eta / sqrt(1 + (/3) * _s)) formula is a crude analytic approximation (it comes from equating variances of logistic and normal distributions and applying a delta-like correction),

  • the integral

    pmarginal()=logit1(+u)(u;0,s2)dup_{\text{marginal}}(\eta)=\int \operatorname{logit}^{-1}(\eta + u)\,\varphi(u;0,\sigma_s^2)\,dupmarginal()=logit1(+u)(u;0,s2)du

    (computed numerically or by GaussHermite quadrature) is the correct marginal probability.

Which is correct / more precise?
The integral (numerical or GaussHermite) is the correct and more precise approach. The plogis(eta / sqrt(1 + (/3) _s)) trick is only an approximation and can be noticeably biased when is moderate/large or when is far from 0. Use the integral / quadrature whenever you want accuracy.

Below I explain briefly why, then give you two practical R implementations:

  • mu_binomial_integrate() accurate, uses numeric integration (slow if called many times)

  • mu_binomial_gh() fast and accurate, uses GaussHermite quadrature (recommended for simulation)

Why the approximation is wrong

The crude approximation assumes the logistic CDF behaves like a normal CDF with variance /3 and then rescales by (1 + variance_ratio). That ignores skew & higher-order moments of the logistic-normal mixture and is only a rough match around the center and for small . In practical GLMM settings (0.3, extreme , small p), it becomes inaccurate.

The true marginal probability is the integral above; evaluating that (numerically or with GaussHermite) gives the true expected probability conditional on s fixed-effect part.

Recommended code

Copy-paste either version below. I recommend using the GaussHermite version for speed + accuracy (use n_nodes = 20 or 50 for high precision).

r
# ------- Accurate version using numerical integration -------
marginal_p_integrate <- function(eta0, sigma_s, rel.tol = 1e-8) {
  if (sigma_s == 0) return(plogis(eta0))
  f <- function(u) { plogis(eta0 + u) * dnorm(u, mean = 0, sd = sigma_s) }
  stats::integrate(f, lower = -Inf, upper = Inf, rel.tol = rel.tol)$value
}

# Find mu such that average marginal p equals p_target (using integrate)
mu_binomial_integrate <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0,
                                  sigma_s=0, p_target, tol = 1e-8, lower=-20, upper=20) {
  eff <- with(design, a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*(x1*x2))
  avg_p_given_mu <- function(mu) {
    etas <- mu + eff
    mean(vapply(etas, marginal_p_integrate, numeric(1), sigma_s = sigma_s))
  }
  froot <- function(mu) avg_p_given_mu(mu) - p_target
  # bracket
  if (froot(lower) * froot(upper) > 0) {
    stop("Failed to bracket root; try wider bounds or check p_target feasibility.")
  }
  uniroot(froot, lower = lower, upper = upper, tol = tol)$root
}

# ------- Fast & accurate version using Gauss-Hermite quadrature -------
# requires 'statmod' package for nodes/weights (or implement yourself).
# We'll use statmod::gauss.quad.prob with normal weighting if available.
# If statmod is not installed, fallback to numeric integrate (above).
mu_binomial_gh <- function(design, a1=0, a2=0, a12=0,
                           sigma_s=0, p_target, n_nodes = 32, tol = 1e-8,
                           lower = -20, upper = 20) {
  eff <- with(design, a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*(x1*x2))

  # helper: marginal p by GH for a vector of etas
  marginal_p_gh_vec <- function(etas, sigma_s, n_nodes) {
    if (sigma_s == 0) return(plogis(etas))
    # get nodes and weights for standard normal GH:
    if (!requireNamespace("statmod", quietly = TRUE)) {
      stop("Please install package 'statmod' for Gauss-Hermite quadrature or use mu_binomial_integrate().")
    }
    gh <- statmod::gauss.quad.prob(n_nodes, dist = "normal")
    xk <- gh$nodes   # nodes
    wk <- gh$weights # weights
    # Integrand: E[logit^{-1}(eta + u)] = sum_k w_k * plogis(eta + sqrt(2)*sigma_s*xk)
    # (statmod gives nodes/weights for standard normal probability measure,
    # so we can directly use nodes*sqrt(2)*sigma_s if using "physicists" GH,
    # but statmod::gauss.quad.prob already returns nodes for the normal pdf weighting.)
    sapply(etas, function(eta0) {
      sum(wk * plogis(eta0 + xk * sigma_s))
    })
  }

  avg_p_given_mu <- function(mu) {
    etas <- mu + eff
    mean(marginal_p_gh_vec(etas, sigma_s, n_nodes))
  }

  froot <- function(mu) avg_p_given_mu(mu) - p_target
  if (froot(lower) * froot(upper) > 0) {
    stop("Failed to bracket root; try wider bounds or check p_target feasibility.")
  }
  uniroot(froot, lower = lower, upper = upper, tol = tol)$root
}

Usage examples

r
# build centered design (example)
coding <- function(nlevels) { levels <- sort(c(0,1, runif(nlevels-2))); levels - mean(levels) }
make_design <- function(m1, m2, reps=1) {
  x1v <- coding(m1); x2v <- coding(m2)
  expand.grid(x1 = x1v, x2 = x2v, rep = 1:reps, KEEP.OUT.ATTRS = FALSE)
}
design <- make_design(2,2, reps=1)

# Example with moderate sigma_s
mu_int <- mu_binomial_gh(design, a1=1, a2=0, a12=0, sigma_s=0.5, p_target=0.1)
mu_int
# fallback: integrate version (slower)
mu_int2 <- mu_binomial_integrate(design, a1=1, a2=0, a12=0, sigma_s=0.5, p_target=0.1)
mu_int2

Practical notes

  • Use mu_binomial_gh() in simulations: it is very fast (vectorised quadrature) and accurate when n_nodes is large enough (1664 nodes are typical; 32 is usually excellent).

  • If you dont have statmod, either install it (install.packages("statmod")) or use the mu_binomial_integrate() fallback (slower).

  • The old formula plogis(eta / sqrt(1 + (/3)*_s)) is only a crude shortcut; dont use it when you need correctness or when is moderate/large. It tends to under- or over-shoot depending on and .

  • When is tiny (0.1), the approximation and the integral give similar answers.

You said:
the size binomial parameter has no role, right?
ChatGPT said:

Correct the binomial size parameter does not play any role in determining (the fixed-effect intercept) when your goal is:

Choose so that the average probability across the design equals p_target.

Heres why.

Why the binomial size does not matter

A binomial response with:

YBinomial(n,p)Y \sim \text{Binomial}(n, p)YBinomial(n,p)

has mean:

E[Y]=npE[Y] = n \, pE[Y]=np

If you want to set a target probability ptargetp_{\text{target}}ptarget, not a target mean count, then the only thing you need to determine is:

p=E[logit1(+s)]p = \mathbb{E}[\text{logit}^{-1}(\eta + s)]p=E[logit1(+s)]

is chosen to solve:

E[p]=ptarget\mathbb{E}[p] = p_{\text{target}}E[p]=ptarget

But importantly:

  • The marginal probability ppp is determined entirely by
    the distribution of =+a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2\eta = \mu + a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + a_{12} x_1 x_2=+a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2
    and the random effect sN(0,s2)s \sim N(0, \sigma_s^2)sN(0,s2).

  • The binomial size n appears only in:

    YpBinomial(n,p)Y | p \sim \text{Binomial}(n, p)YpBinomial(n,p)

    but it does not influence p.

  • Therefore, n plays no role in solving for .

What does size not affect?

  • marginal probability E[p]E[p]E[p]

  • the mapping E[p]E[p]E[p]

  • the integration over random effects

  • solving for

What does size affect?

  • the variance of Y given p:

    Var(Yp)=np(1p)\text{Var}(Y \mid p) = n p (1 - p)Var(Yp)=np(1p)

  • the overall variance of Y (including random effect variability)

  • how well the binomial approximates normality, etc.

But none of these change the required that gives you mean probability = p_target.

Intuition

The target is probability, not expected count.

We solve:

ptarget=E[11+exp((+a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2+s))]p_{\text{target}} = \mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{1+\exp(-(\mu + a_1 x_1 + a_2 x_2 + a_{12}x_1x_2 + s))}\right]ptarget=E[1+exp((+a1x1+a2x2+a12x1x2+s))1]

Nowhere does n appear.

Final Answer

The binomial size parameter does not influence the calibration of when the target is an average probability.

Therefore:

  • The integral-based solver (or GH quadrature version) is correct and size-free.

  • You should not include size when computing .

  • You only include it after simulation, when you generate counts:

r
Y ~ rbinom(N, size = size, prob = p_marginal)

If you'd like, I can show:

  • how size changes the variance of Y across the population,

  • but not the mean probability,

  • with a numerical simulation demonstration.

Here is clean, ready-to-run R benchmarking code to compare speed of the two -solving methods:

  • Method 1 Numerical integration (mu_binomial_integrate())

  • Method 2 GaussHermite quadrature (mu_binomial_gh())

The test compares performance, not accuracy.

I provide:

  1. A small design

  2. Both -solvers (minimal versions)

Benchmarking Code

r
# -------------------------------------------------------
# 1. Small centered design for testing
# -------------------------------------------------------
coding <- function(nlevels) { 
  levels <- sort(c(0,1, runif(nlevels-2)))
  levels - mean(levels)
}

make_design <- function(m1, m2) {
  x1 <- coding(m1)
  x2 <- coding(m2)
  expand.grid(x1=x1, x2=x2)
}

design <- make_design(3, 3)   # small balanced design


# -------------------------------------------------------
# 2. Accurate marginal p via numerical integration
# -------------------------------------------------------
marginal_p_integrate <- function(eta0, sigma_s) {
  if (sigma_s == 0) return(plogis(eta0))
  f <- function(u) plogis(eta0 + u) * dnorm(u, 0, sigma_s)
  integrate(f, -Inf, Inf, rel.tol=1e-8)$value
}

mu_binomial_integrate <- function(design, a1, a2, a12, sigma_s, p_target) {
  eff <- with(design, a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*x1*x2)
  froot <- function(mu) {
    etas <- mu + eff
    mean(vapply(etas, marginal_p_integrate, numeric(1), sigma_s=sigma_s)) - p_target
  }
  uniroot(froot, c(-20,20))$root
}


# -------------------------------------------------------
# 3. Fast marginal p via Gauss-Hermite quadrature
# -------------------------------------------------------
library(statmod)

marginal_p_gh <- function(eta_vec, sigma_s, n_nodes=20) {
  if (sigma_s == 0) return(plogis(eta_vec))
  gh <- gauss.quad.prob(n_nodes, dist="normal")
  xk <- gh$nodes
  wk <- gh$weights
  sapply(eta_vec, function(eta0) {
    sum(wk * plogis(eta0 + xk * sigma_s))
  })
}

mu_binomial_gh <- function(design, a1, a2, a12, sigma_s, p_target, n_nodes=20) {
  eff <- with(design, a1*x1 + a2*x2 + a12*x1*x2)
  froot <- function(mu) {
    etas <- mu + eff
    mean(marginal_p_gh(etas, sigma_s, n_nodes)) - p_target
  }
  uniroot(froot, c(-20,20))$root
}


# -------------------------------------------------------
# 4. Benchmark speed using microbenchmark
# -------------------------------------------------------
library(microbenchmark)

bench <- microbenchmark(
  integrate = mu_binomial_integrate(design, a1=1, a2=0.2, a12=0, sigma_s=0.5, p_target=0.1),
  gh_20_nodes = mu_binomial_gh(design, a1=1, a2=0.2, a12=0, sigma_s=0.5, p_target=0.1, n_nodes=20),
  gh_50_nodes = mu_binomial_gh(design, a1=1, a2=0.2, a12=0, sigma_s=0.5, p_target=0.1, n_nodes=50),
  times = 20
)

print(bench)

In the make_design function, can you include code to produce two categorical variables X1 and X2 where the levels of x1 and x2 appear as A1, A2,... for x1 and B1, B2, ... for x2?

Here is the updated make_design() that:

  • levels named A1, A2, for X1 and B1, B2, for X2

Updated make_design() Function

r
coding <- function(nlevels) { 
  levels <- sort(c(0,1, runif(nlevels-2)))
  levels - mean(levels)
}

make_design <- function(m1, m2) {
  
  # numeric centered coding
  x1_vals <- coding(m1)
  x2_vals <- coding(m2)
  
  # categorical labels
  X1_levels <- paste0("A", seq_len(m1))
  X2_levels <- paste0("B", seq_len(m2))
  
  # expansion
  df <- expand.grid(
    X1 = X1_levels,
    X2 = X2_levels
  )
  
  # match numeric coding for each level
  df$x1 <- x1_vals[ match(df$X1, X1_levels) ]
  df$x2 <- x2_vals[ match(df$X2, X2_levels) ]
  
  df
}
